content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												- This review isn't written by a native speaker, thank you for your understanding -- If you haven't found this review helpful or if you have found a mistake please leave a comment below -Rating Must Play- Key features below ---- Review after -----------------------------------------------Play time needed (perfect) about 45 hoursGaming level from Casual to Gamer.Achievement level between Casual and GamerGame style Third person, hack and slash, adventure, puzzleGame modes Story campaignStory A great story indeed.Playthrough 1 (if you follow my tips, refer to (*))Voice Great.Music Good.Camera Good, sometime nasty.Controls Keyboard and mouse or controller.Tutorial Yes, very good.Unmissable / backtracking content Yes, but refer to (*) or you'll miss several achievements.Download contents DLCGlitches / bugs Yes, refer to (*) and (#).Worth price Full price.- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------This game remembers me the Devil May Cry franchise, even if this one is less difficult than the devil may cry especially the ranking score which is missing. Unlike a Devil May Cry, you can explore an open world. The story is also as great as a Devil May Cry (DMC). As a DMC your currency are souls which are obtained by defeating enemies or opening some chests. There are 3 kinds of souls in fact : health (green), currency (blue) and wrath (yellow). Like a DMC you'll unlock several close and long range fighting weapons, purchase many moves and wrath abilities. Finally there is the famous dungeons and bosses areas.What a great game to feel strong and invincible. I would say if feels like a relaxing game.(#) :One very good glitch at the end of the game, is that you can spawn horsemen as you wish by leaving and entering the area. A very epic fight with your horse.(*) :If you wish to have all achievements you must follow the tips listed below (thanks to a guide on steam) :- Turn off the steam overlay in the game, exit steam (steam -> exit), launch steam and play the game.- You can only play one session of Darksiders in each steam session, if the game crash it counts too. So the famous exit steam (steam -> exit), launch steam and play the game is needed.- Always made saves before the part where you should unlock an achievement if you want to prevent the points above.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Man.. What do I say about Darksiders.. Well, it is by no means a bad game. The gameplay and combat is clean; the puzzles are intriguing enough; the voice acting is fairly well done (especially work done by Mark Hamill); and most enemy designs are intuitive and fun to fight. Speaking of enemies, instant killing enemies is such a joy! However...Darksiders is woefully uninspired. There is absolutely NOTHING original about this game. Everything about the combat, the puzzles, the level/game design, the level up schematic, and even the way you ride your horse (which you won't do very often) is borrowed from other game designs. If you have every played God of War and The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time you will quickly pick up on the tropes and cliches that this game uses. Also, the bosses are simple and gimmicky. Not to mention that the game is fairly easy, even on hard. Lastly, the lore is mildy interesting but the plot and story execution are weak and it just feels like set up for the sequel. Final Word: Don't take my criticism as me not liking the game. I did enjoy it but it is far from being a great game. If you like linear hack and slash action games like God of War and Devil May Cry then you will enjoy this game. However, if you are looking for something fresh, new, and innovative, then Darksiders simply won't fit the bill. P.S I recommend playing with a controller; better layout and feel. Happy Gaming!

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												As something of a dark take on Zelda games, Darksiders is an underrated action platformer that never really attracted as big an audience as it probably deserved. It's not without its flaws - particularly as an unfriendly PC port - but the storytelling and combat are good enough to justify the price of admission.You play as War, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse. Dressed like something out of Warhammer 40K, and wielding a huge two-handed sword named Chaoseater, War has been summoned to Earth to take part in the final battle between angels, demons and man. Or so he thinks. When it is revealed that the horsemen were not in fact summoned, War is accused of taking the apocalypse into his own hands and sentenced to death. He successfully protests, and vows to right his wrong, but also to uncover why he was on Earth if he had not been summoned. War employs a variety of familiar weapons and tools reminiscent of Zelda, but with a twist. The magical boomerang becomes the crossblade (huge shuriken), instead of a bow and arrow War carries a pistol named Mercy, and the hookshot is known as the Abyssal Chain. He also has some magic, but all these play second fiddle to the combo-based swordplay. Three main weapons are at War's disposal: the aforementiond Chaoseater, a mystical scythe, and a powered fist weapon, of which the sword and one of either the scythe or fist can be equipped at any one time. Tapping the attack button for either begins a chain, and you can incorporate attacks from either of his two weapons at any time. Delaying input for half a second at certain points in the combo can open up new combo moves, usually with a situational purpose such as an area attack, and War can also launch and air combo his enemies if he so desires.The weapons and tools have upgrades, not just simply increasing damage but adding new combo moves and abilities, such as a spinning airborne slash for the Chaoseater or allowing the crossblade to bounce between nearby enemies. When things get really hectic, War can transform into a big fiery demon for a short amount of time, greatly increasing the power of his attacks and making him near-invulnerable. The only real problem with the combat is that there aren't enough keys on an xbox controller (mouse and keys are not ideal) to map everything, meaning you'll mostly be sticking to two or three favoured items.Darksiders is a worthy addition to any collection, and clocking in at less than 20 hours means it's good value for money without becoming a drag. The combat is fast-paced and varied, and the presentation while dated is expertly executed. The only real issue with it is the dodgy PC compatability, which you can choose to fix or ignore, and meaning that you'll probably want a controller if you really want to enjoy it.+ Combat is great fun+ The setting and story are well conceptualised- Dodgy PC port

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												This is a fantastic game. I was expecting a cheap God of War Clone, but it's far better than that. For one thing the Horseman War is far more interesting a character than Kratos, whose one-note vengeance act is wearing pretty thin. Great atmosphere, fun combat, very creative puzzles, and some of the best creature design ever. It's a long game with tons of bosses, and they're all awesome looking. New elements are constantly introduced to keep it fresh--grappling hook, horseback combat, and even some Portal dynamics near the end. The biggest criticism is that Darksiders doesn't do anything new, but combining all these great elements from other games so successfully IS something new.

												Darksiders is a game in love with games. content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												A very good single player adventure game with a mature and badass setting and lore. The item mechanics is similar to that of Zelda games while the combat is more that of god of war. This is not a bad thing since they have taken some of the best elements we have seen from other games and perfected it. As long as you are not overly critical and expecting something totally new or original you should not get disappointed.The PC mouse and keyboard controls are even better than the consoles gamepad version since you can now control the camera much more effectively, rendering the occasional tasks of aiming easier as well as less need of focusing the view on specific targets. As long as you map the keyboard layout to your preferences, controls should be precise and combat should be fun and challenging. If you prefer tight gamepad controls, then you can always use a xbox 360 controller.The graphics and effects are nice and colorful with the limitations of that of the consoles Xbox 360 and PS3. The only setting you can change is the resolution so there are no improvements for the PC in those regards.

												I played Darksiders on 360 when it first came out and at first I was disappointed. The combat seemed shallow and I genuinely thought it was going to be a brainless hack n slash from start to finish... oh how wrong I was.  The best way I can think of to describe Darksiders is as a cross between God of War and The Legend of Zelda. Admittedly, the combat isn't as good as GoW's and the puzzles are better in Zelda, but after playing through Darksiders and thoroughly enjoying it I prefer to look at things the other way around: the puzzles are better than GoW's and the combat is better than in Zelda. It really is a AAA game.Get past the slow start and you'll find one of the most underatted games of recent years. And you play as War. WAR ffs! How cool is that?!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												One of the best hack and slash games I've played on PC , up there with it's sequel , Darksiders 2. The game features extremely cinematic fighting and , unlike a number of other games like it , does not rely on QTs quite as much with only the occasional B button.Speaking of the B button , even though this is a PC game , an Xbox pad is highly recommended. Button mashing when it comes to a keyboard is a bit dodgy , even if you are good. This really goes for all hack and slash games since it puts way too much strain on your hardware to make sense using it to smash your foes' faces in.The storyline will pick you up and leave you guessing at the next twist. Just be sure that it will guide you very well onto the end. The game does have open world elements but the path is a little more restricted than I would like. There are a large number of areas but not every part of it is traversable. In Darksiders 2 , there are huge open fields and deserts which give a great feelign of the scale of the world. Darksiders feels kind of squashed into a small area. There is plenty of variety in your foes , though , so there probably won't be many times where you have to stop to look at the view.Problem solving is in the game but is very minimal. Don't buy this if you are looking for puzzles from the old Tomb Raider games.Length wise , the game is sufficiently long to keep you entertained. I would have liked a little more but perhaps it would run out of steam if it was going too long.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2013
												A so called modern update to Link, The Legend of Zelda.  Darksiders is based on The Four Horseman of the Apocalypse though focuses on one, the protagonist War.  What his mission comprises I'll leave to your play-through but he is accompanied by a companion voiced by Mark Hamil of Luke Skywalker fame.  The voice acting is AAA Hollywood material and the characters really come to life because of it.  The combat is substantially solid and the weapons are few but are socket-able via modifiers and they level as well.  The move sets as usually found in this genre are purchasable by souls that you obtain through various methods.  Creative puzzles dominate some sections but may occasionally break the flow of the game.  There are the customary difficultly levels so whether you are an abecedarian or gods gift there's something here for everyone to luxuriate in.  The studio responsible for the production, Vigil Games were newcomers on the development scene when the game was produced but I was surprised to see in the credit roll that Silicon Knights had a hand in development as well.   A stellar production.Nominated.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												The worst you can say about Darksiders is that there's hardly an original bone in its body. The game is broadly a mix of God of War and Zelda, even down to the same structure of dungeons, chests, keys and a horse, but it doesn't reach the high standards of the games it copies, and the art style and tone of the game aren't particularly inspiring either.However, it is solidly-made and usually fun. There are some frustrating bits (one in particularly where I nearly threw in the towel) but if you can forgive the unoriginality and you get on with repetitive enemy encounters, you'll probably find something to enjoy. I found it okay, but I wouldn't particularly recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												I've heard a lot of people call this a Zelda ripoff, which I think is misleading. It's true that a lot of mechanics are ripped straight from Zelda, but it plays very differently.The biggest differences are that it is much more linear and has a higher emphasis on combat. It is definitely closer to a hack'n'slash than an RPG. Fights are almost constant except in some of the more puzzly dungeons and you frequently need to battle wave after wave of enemies. It helps that the combat system has a lot more depth than Zelda games, with six(ish) different weapons, unlockable combos, weapon modifiers, and weapon levels (you gain XP as you fight).It has some minor issues on modern systems (it takes some work to get the in-game cutscenes working and to run at 2560x1440) and can get a little repetitious towards the end but it's still an enjoyable, solid experience.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												"The Heaven hunts you. The Hell hates you."Darksiders is a brutal Hack'n'Slay Adventure.___________________________________________________++Story++In 2010, the Earth is going to be hit by some meteorites. These are not just rocks, but the actual armies of Heaven and Hell, ready to fight each other in an epic battle. Mid in the fight, another man falls from the sky: The Apocalyptic Horseman War. He does not fight for any side in the battle, he is just there to keep the balance, but there is one problem. The Horsemen are only allowed to interfere when the 7 seals are broken. And nobody broke them. War gets teleported to the fiery council, who go into court with him because he broke this rule. He tells them that he has gone to earth because he thought the seals were broken. The fiery council gives him another chance to get rid of his guilt, by killing The Destroyer, the one who started the battle between heaven and hell. So War gets sent back to earth, 100 years after the apocalypse.++Gameplay++The gameplay is a typical Hack'n'Slay. War is badassily strong and gets to fight against a lot of enemies at once. His sword swings hit many enemies at once, and there are other weapons to be aquired with other abilities. The battles feel good and fluid, the finisher moves are brutal and the blocking/evading works great.But there is more than just fighting. The game provides levels and riddles that make it feel like the result of hot sex between God of War and The Legend of Zelda. The riddles can get really hard at times, but not frustratingly hard, so the game does not get boring.There are a lot of collectibles in the open world, and they also help War, like the Abyssal Armor. There are 10 pieces to find, that are pretty well hidden. If you find all pieces, you get one badass armor.Sadly, the programming is weak at times and lets the game crash from time to time. There are also some bugs, like falling through the ground (happened to me 4 times). Good thing that there are enough checkpoints to make up for such annoying bugs.++Grafics++The grafics like a bit comic-like. The characters look extremely packed with muscles, blood squirts en masse, the bosses are huge and monstrous. The environment is very variable, from the destroyed remains of New York over a forest to a huge desert. The light effects look great and the textures are detailed.++Music++Huge, aggressive sounds of orchestral rage are violating your ears in this game. The music fits extremely good with a game where you play as The Apocalyptic Horseman War himself.++Features++Given that Darksiders has a little bit of a comic style, there is also an actual official comic that helps the players understand the lore and get more information about the 4 Apocalyptic Horsemen. Search it on google, it is worth it. ___________________________________________________What to say about this game?God of War + The Legend of Zelda = Darksiders <3

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												As you may have noticed I didn’t write anything on the weekend. I didn’t want to seem too desperate. To make up for it I’ll stay over for a while. Don’t worry, I’ve already cleaned, organized my clothes into your wardrobe and called your mother. Otherwise, here’s a piece on Darksiders. The four horseman of the apocalypse have always been the only remarkable entities in the Bible so Vigil decided that they should be theirs. You play as War because Death is too easy, famine too slow and pestilence… Well what the hell if pestilence going to do? Send you to the nearest emergency room for not washing his hands? But War is the obvious choice for inter-realm bouncing which is exactly what you do. Heaven and Hell are getting too cosy on Earth and you were impugned for it, blah blah blah plot. I mean sure Hell is bad and all, but humans have already been wiped out so I don’t think ‘Stop the Boats’ really applies anymore, especially without Tony Abbott.Other than looking like a complete badass you can swing your sword and shoot your gun. And if you’re clever you can swing your sword and shoot your gun at bad guys. When you’re not doing that you are solving a puzzle that usually involves a ripped off mechanic. By the end of the game you even have a portal gun. That one wasn’t too obvious, no. I will be honest here though, I spent most my time looking over the character in front of a sunset. Or maybe that was a lava-set. I have no idea with apocalypses. In the end it turned out that they didn’t use famine or pestilence, so don’t even get me started on Strife or Fury.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												This is one of those games that is appealing on so many levels. For start, i immediately noticed that the game is designed beautifully, from world to creatures, and ofcourse, the main character which really looks like the embodyment of war, wielding the biggest, and the most badass sword since Buster Sword. Story is very well written and actors did an amazing job voicing those cut scenes followed by memorable soundtrack. As for the gameplay, being the most important aspect of video games in my oppinion, i would say that the developers nailed it.I have heard people comparing Darksiders with Zelda games and i would say they are right, cause Darksiders is one of those multy gameplay aspect games. You will be doing everything from world exploring, treasure hunting, money farming, puzzle solving, character upgrading and battling all kinds of enemies in this game.Exploration is fun and very enjoyable because of the above mentioned beutifully designed world and many secrets that it hides.  Often you will come across new tools that will allow you to revisit all those places you have been at before but now you would be able to reach all those previously inaccessible spots and claim their treasures.Combat is great, and i loved the fact that every enemy is challenging in its own way and that you can easily get outnumbered and usually killed if you dont use all the tools and moves that are at your disposal. Its fairly simple but at the same time, requires concentration and awareness. You will want to learn your enemies moves and try to counter them when they make an opening or by executing a perfect parry which will usually devastate them. Sadly, this game has a reverse difficulty curve, meaning that it will be hardest at the start and in time, combat will become much less challenging as u grow in power. However, boss fights are amazing! They are a perfect blend of combat skills and puzzle, and you can always count on these to provide a fair challenge.Also, you should know that this game is not very well ported for PC. Expect FPS drops in some areas(the Ashlands for me) and even game crashing, which, to be honest, happened to me only once, when i first ran the game and met Vulgrim. You probably wont be able to use controller unless u have original XBOX controller(my PS2 controller would make the game unplayable by fixing the camera at awkward angle simply by being plugged in), and no, x360ce probably wont work for you, so you are stuck with a keayboard and mouse. Another very annoying thing are steam achievements which you will not be able to get unless you are running the game for the first time. Every time you quit and re-run Darksiders, you wont be able to achieve anything. Luckily, this is fixed in seconds by simply quitting steam and re-starting it again but you will have to do it every time you wanna play this game.I usually try to go in details with my reviews but, to be honest, that would be it. Game has a simple concept, A to B route, filled with battle encounters, secrets and occasional puzzles(which are also simple but fun), and its executed perfectly. If you take these bad PC porting flaws out of the picture, Darksiders is an amazing game and likely one that you will remember and recommend

												This game has its ups and downs. I really liked the story, the setting, the skills and the fighting/boss fights. Graphically this game is similar to the Prototype.But what I really disliked was: Tons of different bugs. Many NPCs can just bug out and you will need to relaunch the game. content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												Wasn't expecting much when I first started playing it but man, I'm now glad I did! Its basically Zelda with a lot more mature setting and harder difficulty. You'll want to play on Apocalyptic difficulty or you'll be doing yourself a disservice!The game strikes a good balance between combat, platforming and puzzles. I'll admit it, I was stumped a few times but with enough time and a careful eye you should be able to solve/spot the solutions to the games puzzles. The combat is combo based and requires some precision timing and dodging to do well. You also have various powers and 3 main weapon types that you can weave into the flow. As for the setting its post-apocalyptic but ORIGINAL style, that is, ANGELS AND DEMONS and not nuclear war - I like angel/demon style better. :D Some truely epic sights to behold like a giant goth cathedral on an island surounded by lava, a giant desert with huge sand worms on the hunt and a truely massive demon tower looming in the background (your ultimate goal is to get into that tower). Its all connected via a HUB zone and you can freely travel back to previous areas to get goodies you may have missed like heart pieces (life shards) and bottles (vessels), haha its pretty Zelda-like but thats not a bad thing.So, great game. Basically a mature, goth Zelda. Story isn't anything to write home about but it doesn't get in the way and the characters are all pretty awesome. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												This game is decent and looses points by not being very grounded by design.It takes influence from a lot of games, does only a few of it good. Good example of too many ideas, no proper excecution. It's presentation is alot like God of war, you know, where there has to be a immersion-breaking cutscene for every enemy, every 10 seconds.The combat is boring, despite being the center of the game It's the weakest aspect of it. Poor camera and the annoying targetting (Pressing RT on the controller) gives you finger cramps. The manual targetting for the crossblade and guns is really bad on controller. Darksiders is pretty much DMC, God of War at it's core minus the fixed camera. It's one of those games that tried to be difficult by being extremely cheap and unfair. Enemies have poor A.I but are given extremely high DPS, so you're given the illusion of "difficulty". It's not like Darksouls where everything including the enviroment design constitutes to the difficulty. The boss fights are interesting, some predictable. Worth commeding that the small human size bosses are the most difficult and the big ones are easier, I like this.Darksiders is extremely bloated, some items just thrown in for the chapter and never looked at again (like the horn). Theres alot of backtracking because the first half of the game lenghty fetch quests.What can be praised is the lenght of the game which is quite remarkable and also the repitative but fun puzzles. Both save this game from being a mess.I recommend Darksiders but with patience.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												8.5 / 10 console port game.-1 point for bad mouse control (read con below)-0.5 point for buggy steam achievement (read con below)Bought this game really cheap, so I was not expecting much from it, but it turned out to be a really pleasant surprise.Game reminds me of Onimusha i used to play years ago, the hack and slash action and especially the counter move.Pro:- very good animations. slahsing demons is fun ok- some VERY good puzzles. this is where it surprised me. I was thinking this is a straight forward hack 'n' slash game but nope. Some puzzles took me quite a while to figure out and so you feel really satisfied when you solve them. You might feel annoyed sometimes when you get stuck on a puzzle somewhere and you just wanna get on with the game, but when you do solve it (without looking at guides that is) you will feel very good about it lol- nice musicCon:- biggest con is this is a console port and it's obvious from the EXTREMELY badly done mouse control. Aiming is jerky and not smooth and it makes gameplay really frustrating sometimes- also sometimes keys do not register properly. I died many times when I pressed jump but didn't work for some reason so i just fall off the map and die- very frequent tearing if you don't have vsync turned on- VERY BUGGY STEAM ACHIEVEMENT INTEGRATION.   this is widely known by now. A lot of times your acheveiment will not unlock on steam. In order to get all achievement, you have to shutdown steam, and only launch the game from its exe file. Also never use Steam overlay, especially the browser. and NEVER TAB OUT or the game WILL CRASH.- you get to have 3 weapons, and after you level them all to max, you realize it's all for nothing because at the final boss fight you get ANOTHER SWORD and it's the only weapon that will do damage to the final boss.  This was disappointing.overall:I would recommend this game for its great Hack n' Slash action and VERY SATISFYING puzzles. Can't stress the puzzle part enough, it is REALLY fun. However due to its badly done mouse control and the buggy Steam achievements, it is recommended you only buy this at a discounted prize.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2013
												In short, Darksiders is Legend of Zelda meets bloody apocalypse fighting. It's a fun game as the story was interesting with a decent enough hack and slash fighting system with combos and such. The enemies vary vastly and the bosses are always different. Big lack of PC settings though, you can only change the resolution and v-sync, no aliasing, filtering, etc, just poor port settings. The gameplay, like I said, is similar in vein to The Legend of Zelda, but with a lot more blood. You are War, one of the Four Horsemen sent to confront Abaddon during the final Judgement on Earth. And you fight demons and sheeit, just like Link. The fighting style is even similar, block and attack when possible. Take advantage of enemy weak spots. Roll around and jump attack. Very similar indeed. Even the horse riding and climbing is similar.Still a good game though, despite the flaws with the porting and some minor frame rate issues.8.0/10

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
Introduction : Darksiders is an action role-playing hack and slash video game in which the player takes control of War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. In third-person perspective, the player engages in combat, puzzles, and exploration.[7] The world is divided into separate locations with many areas initially inaccessible until War regains many of his lost weapons and abilities.(+)Graphics : Great graphics presentation, enhanced colours, and superior attention to detail will amaze you .(+)Music :  There are a total of 35 tracks in this game . Each one of them fitting the position you are in perfectly , making you feel epic while .. well .. being epic .(+)Cutscenes :  The cutscenes are absolutely astonishing . They will pull you towards the game even more than you think . They are full of action , with a great animating .(+)Story :  I've always been interesting in these sorts of games . Mythology , Titans , The Four Horseman of Apocalypse sorta things . For me , this game has a great story . (-)Content :  Not good enough , sadly . The problem with the content of this game is that it's too paced . After playing for hours you will release that you have only done a few things . Slash enemies , talk to the guy at the end , he sends you all over the map to collect 4 different items , walk through all the areas , slash more enemies , get all the items and return them back to the guy , then find another guy , who sends you around the map to find 9 items this time ...It could be a lot more fun if a single objective didn't take hours to complete .(+)Controls :  Controls are decent , could use a bit more improving but they won't bother ya .(+)Gameplay :  The gameplay is pretty cool . Slashing through enemies , especially after you get your horse it never gets boring to kill even more . My only complain is that boss fights tend to take really long , but it's classic for games such as this one .It's definetely worth every dollar if you like hack and slash games , and also into mythology and alike .8/10 -   Triskelion Turbella Reviews

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #40 - DarksidersMy first reaction to Darksiders as I played it was that it was very reminiscent of God of War.  I don't consider that a bad thing, but it's hard not to make the comparison as you are hacking and slashing through demons.  But I think it would be a disservice to simply call this a God of War clone, as there are some differences that make Darksiders stand on its own, particularly with it's emphasis on puzzles.The art style has a comic book influence to it, and I thought it worked well.  The only negative is a relative lack of graphic options.  You can change resolutions and set v-sync, but otherwise there are no real customization options.  This isn't a dealbreaker to me at all, and I would still recommend this game.  I'm definitely looking forward to spending more time in it.

content:

												Pros: + Fun mix of gameplay similar to Zelda and God of War+ Interesting story and lore+ Great soundtrack+ Fantastic voice acting, including Mark Hamill in one of the main roles+ Great art directionCons: - No graphics options- Some HUD elements are 720p- Textures are fairly low-res- Some control issues. Can't change control method on the fly, have to restart the game if you want to switch between controller and m+kb- Achievements may not unlockSummary: Fairly decent game, unfortunately it's not a very good port. Still very much playable if you don't mind these issues.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Darksiders is a typical example of what games were like before developers went crazy and started making every game open-world, have some form of multiplayer and flood the consumer with twelve DLC packs.It's a return to the pre-2010 days, when linear action-adventure hack-and-slash games with a little bit of puzzle elements were the norm. This game is linear, but not in a bad way. It doesn't hold your hand at all times, and sometimes it leaves you having to figure things out on your own.The combat system is not super deep, but it sure is entertaining to mow your way through dozens of enemies.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Darksiders was a welcome surprise when I tried it out a few years back. I’m a big fan of the game’s art design and concept, and the gameplay is deceptively simple despite looking really cool. You can watch the game’s opening cinematic on Youtube for a pretty good idea of what to expect in terms of story and style. It’s awesome.First off, it’s an older title so most of you folks should be able to run it with no problem. The game is a 3d “hack & slash” played in third person perspective, but not “over the shoulder.” The game plays well with a controller, but I went through it with keyboard+mouse with no problems.  There’s no “loot” system so you’re fixed in the weapons you can use, but by unlocking different “moves” you can build combos. I’ve heard that the game is really similar to the God of War series in terms of combat, but I’ve never played those so I can’t say for sure. Not only is there a large variety in the enemies you can fight, but there are a bunch of boss battles too. Be warned though that there are puzzle elements to some of the levels which can get very annoying. I had to look online for puzzle solutions a few times.In the story, you play as War, one of the mythical 4 Horsemen who are tasked with preserving “The Balance” between Heaven and Hell.  When the “End War” starts and Hell invades the Earth, it’s time for you to step in kick some♥♥♥♥♥ both demon and angel. After you’re done with the game you might scratch your head a bit trying to figure out what happened (why did this character do that?) but when you’re actually playing it doesn’t pull you out of the game. Also, the ending cinematic really revs you up for the sequel.Overall, the game a definite must play. It’s been in Humble bundles a few times so you might have it without even realizing it. It’s definitely worth your time to play through. A piece of advice though. If you’re playing the game for the first time with the help of an online walkthrough, DON’T collect the Abyssal armor for your first play through. It makes the game too easy.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												I loved parts of this game. The parts that were good were extremely good. The parts that were bad stuck out like a sore thumb. The story was amazing, characters were interesting, and the environment was ridiculously beautiful (as beautiful as a post apocolyptic world can be). This game had everything going for it. Weapon upgrades evenly spaced out giving you enough time to play around with them all without getting bored. I loved the sidequest that had me gather tokens from every zone, giving me rewards for each one i collected. This was the first game I used every single power up because they were ALL useful and beneficial. This is by far one of my personal favorite games I own.     Onto the bad. One thing that frustrated me most is that the Achievements for this game can and will glitch out. I cant even remember how many times i would find all the collectables and realize the game FORGOT to award the achievement and thus result in me having to RESTART THE GAME in order to get it all over again. This is only an issue if you care about achievements, this does not hinder gameplay in any way. The second thing I can complain about is the lack of replayability value to this game. Once you defeat the bosses and aquire the collectables, there is no reason to go back, and the enemies get replaced with weaker ones, making the zone a joke to clear. If this game let me restart with my currencies after i beat it, that would make it much more fun and give me that reason to play it again. But as it stands, once you obtain the collectables and beat the bosses, there isnt much of a reason to continue playing.      In conclusion, this game offered me a great experience while progressing through the story. Problems arose as you start entering your last quarter of the game where there becomes less and less to do. It's great that you aquired all 10 pieces of your abyssal armor set, to bad there isnt much to do in the game by the time you get it other than defeat the final boss with it or use it while obtaining the last few collectables. 8/10 if i were to rate this game. It's great but could've been better with just a few additions.EDIT: apparently you can create a new game after you beat the last boss and start with the abyssal armor if you collected all the pieces in your first playthrough. This is vary nice and does add some replayability.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												This is a great game. I got all of the achievements in 124 hours on record but they could've been done a lot faster, like 40-60 hrs but I had a can of a PC back in the day so...I will do some pros and cons for the gamePROS-Good graphics-Great story-You play with one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse so that's pretty cool-Great mechanics-Great cutscenes-Great character models and art-Almost zero bugs or issues with the game-A lot of gear, weapons and finishing moves and you get a horse to ride on-Great boss fights-You get the Soundtrack with the game-You also get a small comic with the game-Community is really smallCONS-The bugs that are present are game-breaking/achievement-breaking. Game-breaking: when you go through the Serpent Holes, there's a chance of you being stuck in a cutscene when you get out of the Serpent Hole. Achievemet-breaking: achievements only count when you start the game for the first time, if you boot it up and don't restart Steam, the achievements won't count - so just restart Steam when you close the game.I recommend this game. I rate it 8/10 would be War again!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												Heavily inspired by Zelda and God of War which is ultimately a positive thing because both of those franchises are awesome but there is no aspect of the game that does anything better than those two. The combat is pretty basic and very repetitive, it’s not very enjoyable especially compared to other hack and slash games. The story is just a very average fantasy plot, nothing about it feels very unique, interesting or different. The Zelda like dungeons, progression and exploration is the highlight of the game, however there is no music to accompany you while you are doing these things it just kind of makes things feel a little empty, dour and less enjoyable. I also just want to point out how awful and drawn out the portal sequence towards the end of the game was, it completely killed the pacing on the game. My experience with this game was ultimately very boring, the pros of the game are not good enough for me to recommend the game but I can’t say it’s a bad game either. It's overall just a very average action adventure game that can easily be skipped.5/10 (Average)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I almost passed on this game because I could not get it to run. Eventually following the troubleshooting guides, I did and I am very glad I took the time to do this.Darksiders was a very solid action game. The gameplay is similar to God of War and the Batman Arkham series. While the textures and character may lack detail of other games, the action is fast, the framerates are extremely high, the voice acting is superb, and the story is decent.The combat system is interesting, at first it seems if you mash the attack button (a controller is pretty much a requirement for Darksiders), you will kill everything is sight but this quickly becomes not the case. You need to be more careful, dodge, avoid, and counter. A full frontal assault rarely works. I do prefer the Batman Free Flow combat system though and it allows for endless combos a much more fluid experience.To finish the game game you're looking around 13-15 hours, more if you plan on exploring every nook and cranny. I would go 8/10 for Darksiders.

												I'd give this game an 8/10 but for the main character for being the bamf he is the game gets a 9 out of 10. Been one of hell of a ride, entertaining story, and interesting characters. Love the combat system even if I find it very tedious. People liken this to the god of war and Devil May Cry series, I can see it that but I dont know if I see it better than those two series. Combat seems to be forced and a quick way to end it is to smack down an enemy enough and quick kill it (locking yourself into animation and see war obliterate the enemy). For me this combat mechanic doesnt do much for me. Looking forward to booting up Darksiders 2 once I get all the collectibles in this game!

content:
Posted: August 11, 2012
												Heaven and Hell have broken the rules in their eternal battle for supremacy. Instead of taking a side, remind them of their place.You play as War, one of the 4 Horsemen of the Apocalypse. At first I took this title for just another God of War clone. Don't get me wrong, that's not a bad thing. Zelda clone, Metroid clone, these are all great titles to take inspiration from.But that's just the impression at face value, and while it does share many similarities to games like God of War and Devil May Cry, it's almost a blend of the two, with enough interesting and unique aspects to set it apart from either of those franchises and carve its own niche in the genre.I thought perhaps this was going to be like Dante's Inferno, but it's interesting in the sense that you don't side with "good" or "evil" at all, rather you're more of a 3rd, neutral option in the conflict, trying to stop both sides equally.If you enjoy any of the titles mentioned above, you will feel right at home here.

So make sure you're unlocking them as you play.2) Create an extra save right before collecting the final piece for abyssal armor. content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												We have a hopefully first out of four hack and slash games with a story so marvelous you'll be hooked up to your screens from the second you start the game until the end of it. I love the world design which has that special end of the world touch. It has every right to look that way since the story takes place in a time of war between angels and demons in which only the four horseman stand vast in the balance of the world. Story alone is worth every penny of this game. The main character of this game is War. The Badass horseman of the apocalypse which will be one of the most memorable characters you have ever played. The part I dislike about the game is the combat system. You have a massive amount of different combat moves from which you'll end up using only 2-3 in repeat. The other problem with combat system is that War is kind of slow. His moves are sluggish which give enemy a lot of space to break your attacks. Darksiders is a game you should have in your library thought it's a 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2013
												Okay here we go. What can I possibly say about this game. Let's first start and say this game is fun. The controls are smooth and tasteful. The gameplay is fun and insightful and the story is quite intriguing. Now the bad....WHAT THE BLOODY ♥♥♥♥ IS THIS! God of War came out in 2005 and Darksiders came out in 2010. Now this is a good game but I feel as if this is ripping off the hype of the God of War series and before that Devil May Cry and before that, even though there wasn't much of a hype, the Legacy of Kain series. Everytime I play this, I want to just play Legacy of Kain Defiance, Soul Reaver 1 or 2, Blood Omen 2, or even the orginal Legacy of Kain. I just don't get into the game like I do with God of War or the Legacy of Kain series. More so Legacy of Kain. It is worth a buy and is so worth playing. It is fun, addicting, and just plain good ol fashion sending godless heathens back to hell. However; I can't figure out why I want to play the Legacy of Kain series more than this game. Maybe it's because I have a childhood feeling towards Legacy of Kain or if I prefer the story more. Maybe it's because I feel drawn to the characters more.  But maybe....just maybe....the Legacy of Kain series is just better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2012
												Darksiders is a reasonably good game with a bad PC port.  I suggest getting it for a console.  The camera can be frustrating (and has caused some to rage quit), but the open world action and upgrade system is enjoyable if you can tolerate a bit of grinding for resources.Don't expect this game to run well.  It will be choppy.  There will be no video settings other than resolution.  For most of my play, I had my old video card forced to display a smorgasbord of effects at 800x600.  I upgraded from a Radeon HD 3650 to a Radeon HD 7750.  The game was still choppy, but I upped the resolution and it ran just as well.Do not play this game for achievements.  They often fail to register.  If they're really important to you, make sure to save right before so you can try again.  I didn't even get my endgame achievements.  Whats worse is that the game failed to register the armor I collected.  That really hurt because it was supposed to be available on my next playthrough.Darksiders is another game that I ruined by grinding for things I don't need.  This is especially true since I didn't use anything other than a plot item in the final battle.  My weapons were fully maxed.  I finally gave up on my wrath abilities after maxing out two and getting the others one level shy.  I played in spurts over many months trying to complete chores that wouldn't even be registered for achievements.  All I had to do was warp to a location, ride my horse a bit and smack the end boss around.Whatever my complaints, I'd take Ruin over Agro any day. ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Finished Darksiders on Oct. 11th 2014.This game is fun. You play War, one of the four horsemen … to bring devastation on the world. And, oh my, you do. Hell is loose, the angels and daemons are fighting each other and in the middle is mankind. Well, mankind: not long.Soon you find yourself tricked and are “accused” to have been showed up at the wrong time, since noone actually has called for you. You are brought before the cosmic council and you are given a second chance to remedy your “failure”. You are sent back to earth to only find out that centuries have passed since you have been trapped. You are weak and lost all your powers (and your horse). Further more, the council decided to attach an enervating spirit to you which watches every step you take. Step by step – level by level – you regain your powers and abilities back (and finally your horse too). You figure out who is behind your imprisonment and manage to take revenge. It’s a road movie in a post-apocalyptic world roamed by daemons and angels alike fighting each other … and you.The action is pretty cool. You jump, swim, run, crawl, climb, etc. Fighting has some nice moves and as the game goes on you learn new skills and weapons. It really is smooth. The graphics are comic style nice and pretty to watch. The riddles range from easy to pretty awesome. And after learning new skills and abilities you tend to go back to levels you already cleared since you might now discover new places and spots you haven’t been before lacking the ability to fly to these places or even teleport (!). This game has looting features you get hooked on.War is a cool character. … who is lost in a cool though confusing world.The setting has some real nice touch. The world is filled with angels and daemons of all kind fighting each other and you’re fighting all of them. Some boss monsters are huge and some are pretty tough. Still one question remains: why I’m doing all this? What’s the point? The “mighty” council is a bundle of idiots easily fooled by a child or they deliberately sent War to prison … for what? Daemons and angels are fighting because … they don’t know what else to do? Yes, the overall action in the game is very addictive but the story could use some improvements. It seemed that some boy child fantasy has gone wild and just stopped at the point when one starts to justify all the action and reaction the characters in the game perform. “It’s there because … it’s just damn cool, isn’t it?”Finally the controls: I played with my XBox controller on PC. First it starts all nice and easy. Pretty simple and clear. But as you learn new skills, abilities and weapons you find your controller overloaded with zillions of different moves and actions you can do. At the end I felt having about ~40 different key combinations to choose from. And as such I sometimes ended up jumping and flying around before I got the right keystroke to actually hit my foe. This is simply too much.Still, a very pretty entertaining game.7/10

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Wow! I had picked up Darksiders expecting some kind of God of War clone (which it is to some degree) and a so-so experience, but I was totally blown away. The story is actually good and there are some prominent voice actors that you may recognize (such as Mark Hamill as the voice of the watcher) playing important parts here and there. Gameplay-wise it’s basically like GoW with a lot less QTE plus a generous helping of Metroid Prime.A good chunk of the game will have you using various new items and techniques to explore the environment, unlock areas, find upgrades, and solve puzzles in order to advance. Fast travel is implemented in a unique fashion where you enter serpent holes e.g. mini-levels where you run over appearing platforms, giving a bit more of a feeling of going somewhere than just instantly appearing at another location. The controls are pretty solid and I only found myself struggling with them when trying to get war to jump off of climbable walls or when trying to get him on his horse (it doesn’t always respond right away). The AI seems to range from really aggressive to pants-on-head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ depending on the strength of the opponent (small fry will casually stand around as you slaughter their teammates, big guys, not so much). Puzzles in Darksiders are generally more of a matter of finding all the components as some of them have critical parts hidden from plain sight. They’re pretty much just enough of a challenge that it isn’t a cakewalk but still enough to give you the satisfaction from solving them. As far as finding secrets, the game gives you various items that can either highlight their location on specific maps, or one particular enhancement that reveals ALL secrets on the current map (it’s an easy to find enhancement too). Overall I have to say I was pretty satisfied with this game and can’t think of anything really bad to say about it so I’d definitely recommend it to anyone who likes action games with a bit of exploration involved.

												I'd give this game an 8/10 but for the main character for being the bamf he is the game gets a 9 out of 10. Been one of hell of a ride, entertaining story, and interesting characters. Love the combat system even if I find it very tedious. People liken this to the god of war and Devil May Cry series, I can see it that but I dont know if I see it better than those two series. Combat seems to be forced and a quick way to end it is to smack down an enemy enough and quick kill it (locking yourself into animation and see war obliterate the enemy). For me this combat mechanic doesnt do much for me. Looking forward to booting up Darksiders 2 once I get all the collectibles in this game!

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												I had a lot of fun playing this gameFirst thing you notice when you jump into Darksiders is the cool, satisfying combat style the game has. War has a variety of moves, and the controls for the moves aren't very hard, but you still need to memorize them and be quick with your combos in order to beat some bosses and mini-games. The graphics are fine for a 2010 game, voice acting is well done, and the storyline is uniquePros:- Unique style of combat, love to execute big bosses and big monsters.- Fun boss fights- Solid graphics, could be better- Good voice acting- Some really cool environmentsCons:- A lot of puzzles- The game is quite linear, if you miss an important chest, you won't be able to get it at all.- A couple random frame drop spots in the game.- Regular price of the game is hefty for an outdated gameThe good outweighs the bad in this game, I'd recommend you wait to buy it when it's on sale, because it goes on sale a lot, but if money isn't an issue for you, just pick it up and play10/10 would behead demons again.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Previous review was negative due to controller issues, as well as choppy cutscene/audio loss. I have resolved those issues. If you're experiencing the choppy cutscenes and audio loss and you have an NVIDIA graphics card, there is a solution. Use the nvidia control panel and find the options for vsync, make sure it's set to adaptive. Mine was set to allow the 3d application to choose. Darksiders doesn't choose for crap, so make the choice for it ;)Game is actually solid. Not incredibly original, but fun none the less. At 80% off right now, you can't go wrong. Get it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Darksiders, for the uninitiated, is a hack-and-slash game, similar to these in tis' calibre such as Devil May Cry series. In this title, you'll control War, one of the horseman, as a playable character. You can upgrade his abilities, weapons and durability as the gameplay progresses, by purchasing them from Vulgrim, and interactions with other characters such as Samael (Shadow Flight and Chronomancer), and the gate keepers (Shadow realm vision), etc. The action and gameplay are above average for a hack and slash title. However, one of the things you'll appreciate about this game is that there are no freebies: Its' tough and challenging, and both mini-bosses and bosses are no exception. Even on easy, prepare to replay scenes as you battle the main bosses (Notably Tiamat and Silitha, two of the chosen).Visuals: Okay. Scales well even on older hardware with reduced settings. Nothing spectacular here.Game length: Satisfactory.Caveat: The Horseman's steed, Ruin, is acquired much later in the game, and you need him to access some areas in the game. This also compounds into a second problem: Repeatability. You'll find yourself repeating sections later on as you acquire new abilities. This is a tolerable compromise, since the game length does not pack inconvenience in the process (Remember Skyrim? None of that time-packing and stretching is preent ).All in all, it was a great primer to get started on as a game, and its' decent. Overall rating: 8.7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I almost passed on this game because I could not get it to run. Eventually following the troubleshooting guides, I did and I am very glad I took the time to do this.Darksiders was a very solid action game. The gameplay is similar to God of War and the Batman Arkham series. While the textures and character may lack detail of other games, the action is fast, the framerates are extremely high, the voice acting is superb, and the story is decent.The combat system is interesting, at first it seems if you mash the attack button (a controller is pretty much a requirement for Darksiders), you will kill everything is sight but this quickly becomes not the case. You need to be more careful, dodge, avoid, and counter. A full frontal assault rarely works. I do prefer the Batman Free Flow combat system though and it allows for endless combos a much more fluid experience.To finish the game game you're looking around 13-15 hours, more if you plan on exploring every nook and cranny. I would go 8/10 for Darksiders.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												This is not a classic hack and slash game – it's one of those All in One console titles, and a good one too. The action itself is great: enemies are different by design and behaviour, boss fights are creative, combat system has decent variations (though to my opinion not realized to its full potential) finishing moves are gory and induced at will. But fighting and killing takes not as much time as you'd expect: my walkthrough was 14 hours and only 3 hours in combat. The rest of the Darksiders is puzzles. In that respect it takes inspiration not solely in DMC games, but from Prince of Persia, Legacy of Kain, hell - even Portal. Some of the puzzles feel forced and artifitial, but most of them are creative and engaging.One of the best hack and slash titles on PC for sure

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I usually don't play this type of games, but thought I'd try to play something different for a change. Maybe that's also the reason why I liked it so much. This game got me captivated from the first seconds, thanks to the constant epicness of the the game universe. The gameplay is also breeze. There are large number of different moves the player could make, which looked a bit intimidating at first, but in the end a set of few moves is enough to get through most fights (at least in normal difficulty). All boss fights were manageable after a few tries.Yes, there were also plenty of downsides. The console port is of quite poor quality. The keyboard+mouse controls work well, but the keybindings are a bit strange at first. The game crashed quite a few times and also features a very annoying bug where steam achievements are not registered unless you restart steam before playing the game. Running around the map also got boring towards the end. Still, you can live with these and the game is definitely worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2013
												An original IP that is based on the 4 horesemen of the apocalypse. Similar to the Zelda franchise: you explore dungeons while acquiring weaponry and items that help in reaching otherwise unreachable areas and equipment that helps in various ways from powering up to revealing hidden chests on the map. If you like the Zelda franchise, this is pretty much up your aisle. The only downside is that there are only 5 dungeons, although the last one is so damn long it might as well count as two. But for 20 dollars, the price justifies the length and originality in the IP. It should take around 20 hours to complete; so a dollar an hour. More bang for your buck than going to the movies.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												I had a lot of fun playing this gameFirst thing you notice when you jump into Darksiders is the cool, satisfying combat style the game has. War has a variety of moves, and the controls for the moves aren't very hard, but you still need to memorize them and be quick with your combos in order to beat some bosses and mini-games. The graphics are fine for a 2010 game, voice acting is well done, and the storyline is uniquePros:- Unique style of combat, love to execute big bosses and big monsters.- Fun boss fights- Solid graphics, could be better- Good voice acting- Some really cool environmentsCons:- A lot of puzzles- The game is quite linear, if you miss an important chest, you won't be able to get it at all.- A couple random frame drop spots in the game.- Regular price of the game is hefty for an outdated gameThe good outweighs the bad in this game, I'd recommend you wait to buy it when it's on sale, because it goes on sale a lot, but if money isn't an issue for you, just pick it up and play10/10 would behead demons again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Wow! I had picked up Darksiders expecting some kind of God of War clone (which it is to some degree) and a so-so experience, but I was totally blown away. The story is actually good and there are some prominent voice actors that you may recognize (such as Mark Hamill as the voice of the watcher) playing important parts here and there. Gameplay-wise it’s basically like GoW with a lot less QTE plus a generous helping of Metroid Prime.A good chunk of the game will have you using various new items and techniques to explore the environment, unlock areas, find upgrades, and solve puzzles in order to advance. Fast travel is implemented in a unique fashion where you enter serpent holes e.g. mini-levels where you run over appearing platforms, giving a bit more of a feeling of going somewhere than just instantly appearing at another location. The controls are pretty solid and I only found myself struggling with them when trying to get war to jump off of climbable walls or when trying to get him on his horse (it doesn’t always respond right away). The AI seems to range from really aggressive to pants-on-head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ depending on the strength of the opponent (small fry will casually stand around as you slaughter their teammates, big guys, not so much). Puzzles in Darksiders are generally more of a matter of finding all the components as some of them have critical parts hidden from plain sight. They’re pretty much just enough of a challenge that it isn’t a cakewalk but still enough to give you the satisfaction from solving them. As far as finding secrets, the game gives you various items that can either highlight their location on specific maps, or one particular enhancement that reveals ALL secrets on the current map (it’s an easy to find enhancement too). Overall I have to say I was pretty satisfied with this game and can’t think of anything really bad to say about it so I’d definitely recommend it to anyone who likes action games with a bit of exploration involved.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												An often underlooked 3rd Person Action-Adventure game, with very satisfying combat, some open-worldy(ish) exploration and a gorgeous art style. Unfortunately this game also has one pretty major flaw/bug... Achievements. Or rather, they don't work properly. I HIGHLY recommend closing Steam entirely and re-opening it before launching this game (same goes for if you tab out) if you plan on getting every achievement in this game, or else many (for some unknown) reason may not unlock, forcing you to replay that section. It is also worth noting that I played this game with an Xbox 360 controller due to it's genre, and found the overall experience very enjoyable.Worth it, but not at full price.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												This is one of those games that you have to give a chance, cause you won't likely fall inlove with it immidiately. To my surprise though I liked this, more than the sequal.Has many clever puzzles and enjoyable boss fights that each have their own gimmic to win. It's sort of like a gorey zelda clone.The biggest issue I had with this game, was that I constantly felt under powered. The lowest level enemies take several hits to dispatch until the end. Didn't really find myself using anything more than 2-3 moves and the default sword  the entire game. Would really of liked to see more useful unique weapons as you progressed to replace it. There are other weapons, but their usefulness is debatable.WARNING:1) There seems to be a bug for some, where you have to restart steam everytime you play or you won't unlock achievements. So make sure you're unlocking them as you play.2) Create an extra save right before collecting the final piece for abyssal armor. You'll need to load that save and recollect the final piece everytime you want to start a new game with the abyssal armor.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I came into Darksiders expecting a God of War and Zelda mashup with lots of Biblical imagery and a cardboard cutout of "War" smashing things like Hulk. What I got was just as expected, aside from War, who is a much deeper character than I initially thought.The game plays out pretty well, starting easy and showing all the neat stuff War can do so you can get a feel for his power before the tutorial is over and you have nothing. From there it's a smash-em-up beatfest of demons and angels alike to clear his name, and lemme tell you the plot is above-standard for this sort of thing. When I played God of War I played a guy who was out to kill a god and damn anyone who got in his way because of personal vengeance. When I played Darksiders I saw War thinking things through, talking with people rather than outright attacking them, and his goal was to clear his name so he could do his ultimate duty as a Horseman of the Apocalypse. He's not doing this whole song and dance for himself, he's doing it to keep the balance of existence.Ultimately I would recommend this game to anyone who likes a modern twist on the Apocalypse, loves to collect things, has fun figuring out God of War combos, and enjoys a good story with a decent challenge when playing on the highest difficulty.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												The common concensus is that the 'next Zelda has come'. While I cannot agree with that, because honestly Darksiders just isn't that good, the game does come closer than any other before it. The art is fantastic and so are the voices. If anything, I'm more reminded of Soul Reaver than of Zelda. Darksiders is a solid game with rewarding combat and sensory delights. It can be repetitive and more than a little exhausting to play. And at times what it demands the player to do to progress can be excrutiatingly vague. Yet it is a rare duck and one worth playing, even if only for the purposes of demonstrating an endangered genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												What about Darsiders? : Darsiders is an Action Adventure Fantasy with a pinch of RPG but mainly Hack&Slash game.You are WAR, one of the 4 Horsemen of the Apocalypse and you have answered the call of the 7 seals bringing Chaos and Destruction on Earth. But something isn't right, it seems that you have been deceived by the Forces of Evil becasue the 7Seals are still intact. Brought to the Council, you have been accused of breaking the Truce between Hell and Heaven and started the War which see the Destruction of Earth. Stripped off your Powers, you are send back to Earth to uncover the truth and those responsible the treachery and seek Revenge.The plot as you can see is interresting and keep you going as you can't wait to find out who's behind all this, the graphics are really good and most of all even if it was a console port, the Devs have made an effort to optimise Keyboards and Mouse users, and i really appreciate that.The character is well designed, the attacks options and variety of moves make the game quit enjoyable, some very nice cutscenes to keep you hook up and also huge end Bosses to test your skills.There are also some RPG ingredients and you can upgrade your character with more powerfull gears and items, souls of your victims are used as currency so the more you kill the richer you get yeah that's evil :D.Overall Darsiders is a great Action game, well worth getting specialy right now when Steam Summer Sales is on, you will not regret it, i clearly didn't.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2012
												It's got a generic story with various blatantly borrowed influences from classics such as Zelda, God of War and Portal (?!). Aside from these flaws, the game sports a fairly impressive and responsive combat system which makes taking down hordes of enemies a gore-tacular breeze, although it does become repetitive. The level design is great however, favouring a dungeon-like free-roaming hybrid over that of conventional level systems, arguably to its own benefit. The in-game collectibles are challenging to complete and offer incentives to explore, offering a reason to diverge from the story path. The voice acting is rubbish, the story predictable and the soundtrack painfully generic, although this really is a fun, long-lasting experience, eased by an expansive weapons and combo system and a lovably gothic art direction with excellent graphics. Oh and the boss battles are welcomely grand.7/10

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												The best way I can describe the Darksider series is an interactive book.  The lore is so creative and so good, the driving force for me to push into the game was to findout what was going to happen.  The story line was that good for me.  The overall gameplay I enjoyed, however there is one complaint.  It basically happens in the last dungeon, but the pace of the game drastically changes.  There are puzzles throughout the game, but the last dungeon got pretty rediculous quick.  I guess I am dumb, but I had to go to walkthroughs to finish the last dungeon.  The pace of the game drastically slowed down.  The fighting is somewhat challenging, but I personally didn't need all the various combos at your disposal.  I stuck with the very basics, and was able to beat the game just fine.  Which totally negates the point of having those.In retrospect, they could of done things differently to make the game even better, but I will say the game as it is is very worth it.  The cliffhanger at the end of the game is just so cool.  And it sets you up for the second Darksiders, and makes you eager to play the next game in the series.

												You will find that playing this game with a keyboard / mouse combination is klunky and you will achieve the success rate of getting very upset.  For 1, you must keep in mind that this game is a "console port". That's right! What gives that away? don't kid yourself.. during game play you will see "Xbox360-like" buttons for your decision making. Yes, that was my 1st clue. I semi-ignored that and continued playing without using my xbox360 controller (wired or wireless... it simply doesn't matter. That my friends, is based on your own personal preferance. I tried playing with my keyboard/mouse and I gave up. After trying to initiate my glide power with wings.. it was hard to get that to work. SPACE bar just didn't operate smoothlyand I died...A LOT! I guess that this is my only "Con" for playing this game. Other than that, the story line is 1 of thee best!It's a 5 out of 5 kick butt goodness game!

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												If you are a Zelda Fan, this is the game for you. Pretty much identical to a Zelda game: Dungeons, Hearts and Containers, Souls (Rupees), and most importantly IMO the concept of using items you get in dungeons to advance through the game and kill the bosses. There's also an element of Portal later in the game as well, so if you like Portal then that is a plus.My one main criticism is the storyline. There are 5 dungeons, and the vast majority of them involve getting the hearts of the chosen - the story really takes place during the beginning and end of the game aside from meeting Ulthane. Also, I'll mention some items are MISSABLE - particularly all items in the final dungeon.If you like Zelda, you'll like Darksiders. If you love Zelda, you'll love Zelda. Get this game if you haven't. Now. It's a 9/ 10.What are you doing here reading this? BUY THIS GAME!!!!Okay you must be bored.  So go have some fun! Buy Darksiders Today!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I came into Darksiders expecting a God of War and Zelda mashup with lots of Biblical imagery and a cardboard cutout of "War" smashing things like Hulk. What I got was just as expected, aside from War, who is a much deeper character than I initially thought.The game plays out pretty well, starting easy and showing all the neat stuff War can do so you can get a feel for his power before the tutorial is over and you have nothing. From there it's a smash-em-up beatfest of demons and angels alike to clear his name, and lemme tell you the plot is above-standard for this sort of thing. When I played God of War I played a guy who was out to kill a god and damn anyone who got in his way because of personal vengeance. When I played Darksiders I saw War thinking things through, talking with people rather than outright attacking them, and his goal was to clear his name so he could do his ultimate duty as a Horseman of the Apocalypse. He's not doing this whole song and dance for himself, he's doing it to keep the balance of existence.Ultimately I would recommend this game to anyone who likes a modern twist on the Apocalypse, loves to collect things, has fun figuring out God of War combos, and enjoys a good story with a decent challenge when playing on the highest difficulty.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												The common concensus is that the 'next Zelda has come'. While I cannot agree with that, because honestly Darksiders just isn't that good, the game does come closer than any other before it. The art is fantastic and so are the voices. If anything, I'm more reminded of Soul Reaver than of Zelda. Darksiders is a solid game with rewarding combat and sensory delights. It can be repetitive and more than a little exhausting to play. And at times what it demands the player to do to progress can be excrutiatingly vague. Yet it is a rare duck and one worth playing, even if only for the purposes of demonstrating an endangered genre.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												I was searching for a game like this after playing Bioshock series, Dishonored, Deus Ex etc. That is a game with both a good story and gameplay. That is what I (kinda) found here. The gameplay seems similar to the Batman games (not that positive for me). Sometimes, espessialy when you're getting closer to the end, the combat seems a bit boring. Yes, as you progress you encounter new, stronger units but if you repeatedly block/dodge and hit then your fine. There are many puzzles you need to solve (some would say a bit complicated), yet none of them are hard if you've played portal. There are some collectables that are kinda easy to find, thus there are not that many. It offers *roughly* 15-16 hours of gameplay (add another 5 hours for 100% completion. Gameplay wise, I wouldn't buy it for killing demons or angels.BUT!The story of the game seemed really appealing to me from the first minute! I was finding myself getting too bored to play (because it was dodge - kill, dodge - kill all over again) but at the same time I was magnetized by the story and wouldn't let go. I haven't played the sequel yet but I really look forward to.OVERALL I DO recommend the game, yet I'd wait for sales.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												The Good: Typical stylized action game in the sorts of God of War/DMC, Tons of platforming/puzzles, fluid combat, great and personally very intriguing action. Unique hero.  Great graphics for 2009.  Memorable characters. Rewarding back tracking, and exploration. Platforming items used to defeat bosses/enemies, actually very comfortable controls for a console port. The Bad: Not enough itemization or character depth. The Ugly: Unclear objectives in puzzles, unclear waypoints to progress. Extremely ambiguous expected ways of killing certain bosses which turn into feedfests till you figure it out. Tedious mid-late end game.Was at first put off by the reviews on here of the game with people saying "Horrible graphics, controls etc." But I bought it, and  actually liked this game a ton. If you like action games, I would give this game a go, especially on sale. Very fun, unique, and love the storyline. Afterwards feel free to pick up Darksiders 2! 8.5/10

												I don't have too much things to say about  Darksiders 1 , so here's a short explanation about this game.I recommend use a gamepad unless you wanna shout and kill someone, because it's a port. FOR ME, it was a dense casual hack and slash game with EPIC things, and sometimes a "rly? y u do dis 2 me dolan" things. PROS + EPIC character model & environment+ Nice combat mechanics+ Good boss battles with different tactics+ More than 15hs gameplay+ Great shop system+ Lot of fun killing hordes+ Music+ Voice acting+ Cutscenes are well done+ Weapons can level up+ Collectables = Rewards <3 CONS - Impressive Puzzles for a 3 years old kid- You can't skip cinematics- Lot of bugs- Steam Achievements bugged- Not 100% open world (you need to "unlock" some parts)- Pixeled 2D Background- You need to run a lot *SPOILER AHEAD*  then you get a horse - That PS1-like repeated task: you need to go to 3 different ways to get 3 different items because you need to open a gate that is in the middle of those 3 paths (God please, staph)- The "Serpent Hole" was not neccesaryScore: 7 / 10

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I can't leave a review for Darksiders 2 since the deathinitive edition came out, so instead I'll talk about both games here. The first installment always make me think of the Legend of Zelda, Ocarina of Time. It has a great mix of puzzles and combat, some challenging and some just fun. The second installment is even more enjoyable with lots more great content and more varied combat and tactics possible, so it keeps you interested for much longer. Both games already looked great, so I'm sure the deathinitive edition will only make it look better. Maybe someday I'll get that edition to play through it all again. Overall, I highly recommend both games for great storyline, fun combat, and challenging puzzles.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												19-Apr-2016 : Finished main story + extrasEquipment : MSI GT80-2QE NotebookREVIEW : Graphics are a bit outdated since we're talking about 6 year old game here, but I think it is pretty good compared to other 2010 games. The gameplay took the best part of Soul Reaver, Devil May Cry and Portal. The story and characters are unique with good voice acting and soundtracks.The story ends with a cliffhanger and I can't wait to play as the other three horsemen. It took me 19 hours to complete it on the highest difficulty setting and I didn't even feel it, time just flies. This should be a sign of a good (if not great) game.CONCLUSION :Recommended on full price, a must-have on sale price.PS :* To unlock Steam Achievements properly, always restart Steam before running Darksiders.* To unlock the Xbox/PS3 pre-order bonus, The Harvester Scythe, hex edit the save file.
