Even if the game looks old, it defenetly doesn't feel like it. All throughout the game it made me feel so adventurous, without discarding action and 'gore'. It actually manages to make you feel powerful without making the game easy-mode, even normal difficulty has its challenge. The story is 10/10, great plot development and game overall. I defenetly look forward to new games for this series.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												The reality is there are a lot of good ideas in darksiders but they are not executed well, the game is poorly paced and the story bits while possibly interesting aren't really well put together.  Darksiders really wants to be an action game but takes it's que from zelda (aka there's barely anything to do inside darksiders world).  Where everything is by the numbers and hand holdingly linear from start to finish.  The enemies you fight aren't interesting and wars controls are a bit rough, especially with the stickyness of the dodge mechanic.Pick this game up only at a discount or only if you don't mind bland slow games.  There is no "maybe button" so I'm putting a yes only if you don't mind playing games with serious flaws.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Sure, Darksiders took a lot from the Zelda games, but DmC Devil May Cry took a lot from this game: gliding on angel wings, press V for Super mode, using powers in puzzles, killing enemies turns them into skulls which function as currency, buying little consumables in stores using skull money, ALL the moves with the Scythe and Fist weapons.  It's a good formula. Although it's 2009 release date and shoddy port still shows--there are no graphics options other than resolution and V-sync--it's still a pretty good open world RPG. The combat is great, the pacing is not great (think Assassin's Creed I). If it goes on sale, I'd say pick it up.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												I will consider various sides of this game, trying to be the more objective as possible.These sides are:♦ The Gameplay♦ The Graphics♦ The LoreLet's ride!♦ The GameplayThis is probably the most boring game I've ever played.It's a classic Action/HnS like God of War, but unlike the Sony's pillar this game is repetitive and predictable.There are very little combos, made only with the main attack button and the move control.There are tons of enemies, but the vast majority are just retexture of previous encounters with higher stats or in larger groups.The only difficulty is that in some parts of the game there are a few of overpowered enemies that only make the game more frustrating without adding any true challenge.The platform/puzzle sections are nice since you don't have any suggestion and you just have to find the way by yourself.♦ The GraphicsThis is very controversial.The texture of the characters are beautiful and ashtonishing, but the same can't be said for the enviroment and for the models: the ground looks gross and the models are too pointy. Even how the texture are placed is horrible.The game overall looks like an HD remake of a PSX game.♦ The LoreThis is the only point where i can't find a leak.It's awesome. A tittle too slow thanks to the gameplay, but it's how games should be played.DarkSiders in a nutshell:((-Slay tons of enemies-Drag stuff around-Slay more enemies-Destroy stuff-Slay a miniboss) Repeat x10-Slay enemies-Kill a Boss) Repeat x10I can't suggest you to buy this game for full price, but if you like the genre very much and/or it's on sale, buy it!6/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I'm giving "Darksiders" a QUALIFIED recommendation here.  The qualification is that you should only buy it if you love games where it takes ridiculous keystroke combinations (or controller-fu if you've got a controller) to fight your way through the game.  This game is not for me.  At about the 11 hour point (where somehow, some people claim they've finished the game), I finally got to the first real boss (Tiamat) and I've got to quit.  I can't handle the keystroke combinations.  In desperation, I tried using a controller, and have the same problem (of course, that's probably because I almost never use a controller and haven't been using one to get to the point I'm at).  So, that's the big negative.  There are also a few other smaller issues with the game.  First, the menus have issues with being a bit tough to understand.  And second, there's a problem with Achievements not registering (look in the discussion forums for a work around).  But, otherwise, the game is nicely done with very high production values.  I wish I could have pushed my way through.  But, unfortunately, I can't.

												They took the Zelda game formula  and for a time it works, but as it goes on it just gets boring.  There is this dungeon where you have to climb three towers to fight the same miniboss over and over,  and collectibles you have to backtrack beaten dungeons just to pick up when you have the tool to do so. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Darksider is a great game , NO DOUBT..... I have friends who says that its a rip off from the famous Play Station game god of War- but I care a damn cause I never going to own a PS at the first place. I know it is a bit late for a full length review - cause the entire gaming world has played that game way before I decided to write this review. So by cutting the crap let be put things straight what I think of the game -  Story - This is definitely not the strongest of the point for this title. The story is based upon a post apocalyptic world. :There is a fight between the Heaven and Hell and the battle field is the Earth. Hell invaded the Earth and one of the Four Horsemen, our hero "WAR" is summoned. But there are no sign of the other 3. what happened then ?? who and why summoned WAR ??? The story moves on from here.... Still a bit boring Gameplay -  This is a deal maker. The gameplay is very swift and the control are well optimized for the controllers. People from controller world will enjoy it. I myself is playing this game on my XBOX 360 controller for PC; enjoying it thoroughly. There are different abilities and items and upgrades that you can use according to your play style. items have active as well as passive abilities over the playing character. The environment is very interactive. And you get a tons of secrets to unlock. Coupled with the steam achievements the experience is very rich. Graphics - The graphics is well complementing the gameplay. After all it is a hack and slash RPG that is set on a post apocalyptic scene. The levels look stunning and so as the character models. The models change with the abilities that are being used by the character; for example you get a flaming red sword or you add life steal then you get a green overlay. The environmental items are well designed. But I did found 1-2 occasional glitches in the game, but I am sure that can be ignored for sure. In other words - very pleasing for my eyes. The hack and slash fight sequences are very much of an eyecandy.Overall the game is a must play for RPG fans, hack and slash fans and should be played by any gamers, so to speak off. I got the bundle Darksider 1 and Darksider 2 together - icing on the cake.Go buy the game and play it ..... I hope that you will enjoy it as much as I have.P.S. the in game audio is awesome too :)

												EDIT:As of now after encountering all these obstacles and finally being able to play again I feel I'll redo this review slightly while I still dislike the gameplay and technical state this port is in. I will say this game still has been very fun and sorry if I didn't make that as clear in the original, this game was running the meh opinion and with only 2 options it was hard to pick but will the frustration with some of the technical issues I chose the latter. However I'll revise and give it a recommend because I was able to actually continue on and finish it.This will be the first game I don't recommend and for good reason. While the game itself is enjoyable and awesome (makes the cons even worse really) is the fact that the game is not very stable or reliable and Im referring to gameplay stability rather than actually running the game. There are some bugs which can screw you over here and there but while playing I brushed them off, however the straw that broke the camel's back was the irreversible literal game breaking puzzle bugs. I made it as far as turning in the four hearts and was backtracking for collectibles/armor/shards etc. While doing so my character is now forever locked in the Hollows because of the train puzzle. Ther is no physical way of me leaving the dungeon now and I really didnt feel like giving up another 10hrs of my playtime to just finish the things the game had broke for me. 5/10 phenominal game, terrible pc port

content:
Posted: June 25, 2011
												If you love Zelda like I do there isn't really much choice if you want a similar game on the PC. So you're stuck with Darksiders really. It's pretty good, the graphics are decent (I still have a feeling it lacks something, I don't know why) and the dungeons are pretty cool and cleverly made. One thing I didn't really enjoy was the God Of War-like combat. There are just too many fights (I don't mind bossfights obviously) and it just felt like button mashing all the time. What I'd rather see is an 'open' world where you can explore things, yes, just like Zelda. So, for Darksiders 2: less combat, more exploring. Give us that and it will be a brilliant game ! This is a good start nonetheless, give it a try.[Rating: 86/100]

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												The start of this game is fairly slow, introducing you to combat and the world and therefore drags a bit as there's really not much you can do in terms of combat initially. You earn more weapons and techniques for them throughout the game and the battle system eventually becomes quite well fleshed out. While not on par with Bayonetta or the later DMC titles, it's still got enough to work with that it can be fun.Once the game introduces you to the dungeons it becomes a lot more fun and interesting and the first two dungeons are great, rivalling some of Zelda's best with some good bosses to round off the experience. Unfortunately the game begins to fall flat at around the halfway point with the latter two dungeons being much less interesting and the bosses being a bit lame. There is no final dungeon and the final battle isn't very challenging or engaging at all. To top this off, there's a bit of padding before the final dungeon which is really just backtracking and busywork, not aided by the poor map system.The story is there but it's not something I was really invested in. I don't really care much about the characters and there weren't any great moments.Overall I'd say this game is probably worth a play if you're into Zelda and want something that's similar but changes the formula up a bit. While it does dip towards the end, I feel that the first two dungeons at least are worth playing the game for if you get it cheap.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I'm giving "Darksiders" a QUALIFIED recommendation here.  The qualification is that you should only buy it if you love games where it takes ridiculous keystroke combinations (or controller-fu if you've got a controller) to fight your way through the game.  This game is not for me.  At about the 11 hour point (where somehow, some people claim they've finished the game), I finally got to the first real boss (Tiamat) and I've got to quit.  I can't handle the keystroke combinations.  In desperation, I tried using a controller, and have the same problem (of course, that's probably because I almost never use a controller and haven't been using one to get to the point I'm at).  So, that's the big negative.  There are also a few other smaller issues with the game.  First, the menus have issues with being a bit tough to understand.  And second, there's a problem with Achievements not registering (look in the discussion forums for a work around).  But, otherwise, the game is nicely done with very high production values.  I wish I could have pushed my way through.  But, unfortunately, I can't.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Well this was fun to play if you are into the hack and slash style of playing. I reminded me of the Castlevania Lord of Shadows kind of fun. Once you get used to your controls, the game is pretty good. Though you may have to resort to watching YouTube video on walkthroughs and how to deal with certain situations, it's not always obvious on what you have to do like fighting Tiamat. It's not a boring game to play since you have to go through many different places, like the desert, the water, underground sturctures, lava pits, etc... the different environments and different bosses you fight keeps things interesting.The only downside I saw is that a few achievements that should have been unlocked, did not unlock. Could be a bug, but it doesn't affect game play. So it's up to you on how annoyed you would get by not getting an achievement you are supposed to get. Perhaps when I try on the second time around, it will unlock.I quite enjoyed it myself that I went and bought Darksiders 2. I will be playing Darksiders again in the future it was that good for me.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Coming from Dark souls, the combat in this game feels MUCH MUCH more boring. Basically, with the sword, you spam (X), and occasionally, whenever you fancy you can hold (X) to do an artorias flip.  And even with the tweaks and a controller the input feels incredibly laggy and inresponsive, which makes dodging enemy attacks very frustrating. You'd figure that in an 'action' game at least the actions will be good, but apparently this is not the case.Anyways, if you get it from a bundle by all means try it out for yourself but I wouldn't recommend this. I'm probably not going to finish this either cause there're much better games out there.Also, terrible PC port, NO ♥♥♥♥ING GRAPHICS OPTIONS AT ALL! You can only change resolution, V-sync and brightness, that's it. V-sync also doesn't work and you have to use the NVidia Panel.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												If you don't mind solving puzzles in an action-adventure game, then please skip my review and buy this game. Darksiders runs smoothly, has great art style, fun and brutal combat and a cool sword.BUT if you're not into puzzles, then this game might not be for you.At first, the game feels very much like an epic metroidvania God of War, which is cool. There are puzzles here and there and that's fine.But later in the game, the dev got too carried away with puzzles and the balance shifts heavily from action-and-puzzle to puzzle-and-puzzle-and-puzzle-and-puzzles. I don't mind repetitive combat and weapon/skill upgrades that don't evolve to anything much. However, running around trying to figure out seemingly endless stream of puzzles with not enough actions in between isn't something I expect from a guy named War.Again, if you like a lot of puzzles in your action-adenture game, then you'll have a great time. But this isn't for me.

The upgrades become stale and not worth the playtime at endgame. I'm already thinking of starting Darksiders 2 without finishing the first.This game reminds me of the  God of War series with almost identicle gameplay and graphics style. It has a good story about a war between Heaven and Hell,and is fun to play.Originally released for Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 in January 2010.


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



You play as War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.As the story goes,someone Disturbs  the balance between Heaven and Hell and War gets the blame. The Horsemen are supposed to only be Summoned when The appropriate Seal for each Horseman is broken, although  something summons War without breaking the Seal that summons him.Gameplay-Hack and Slash button combos,when you do enough damage to a foe an input prompt (B) for a finishing move will pop up over their head. You hit the button and it kills the enemy with a short animation. Darksiders provides about 15 hours of single-player content.I've been playing 20+ There's lots of gear to collect, weapons to upgrade, combos to learn, and special items to find. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												The most tryhard hero ever (can't even speek a word without trying to speak extra grim while giving the impression he is getting tortured right at that moment) in a very unimaginative story (apocalypse, demons and stuff) goes on an endless quest to fetch stuff for some demon or something. He can also fetch other stuff.I mean, i can understand this game is not about story, but it all feels like a careless hull for the actual heart of the game: The Combat. Unfortunately the combat is not that good. After having played games like Dark Souls and DMC 3/4/Reboot, the combat is just a lot worse than all of those and just does not feel exciting imo.The enemies patterns are very easy to learn and once learned you just grind down the health of the bigger enemies / bosses (the smaller enemies can be pretty much ignored.) An exception are the angels (in groups), which are actually interesting to fight because of their ranged attacks, but that does not make up for the rest. Hit-n-Run tactic almost always works.The manual aim mode is too slow to be effective in combat most of the time. The weapon update system is very simplistic and once you have found your favorite weapon upgrade, thats it (you can only mount one update per weapon, though you can switch between 2 weapons and you have an offhand ability which can also be upgraded).There are puzzles and platform elements, though neither are challenging in any way. Instead of few bigger puzzles (which i would have preffered) there are a lot of small push-that-button or push-that-box-to-climb-up or light-that-torches-to-blow-up-things type puzzles, they arent too bad i guess. The hero can climb and swim really fast, which i REALLY liked. So points for this stuff.When it comes to graphics (which of course are outdated by now), the overall art style fits together nicely. There is only one problem: The hero. His running looks bad. He runs like a poorly animated dwarf. This adds in making his tryhard character appear quite rediculous and out of place. Bonus points in design for these big living Rock-Portal-Blockers though. Sound is okay.TLDR:Mediocre gamplay. The hero's way of taking anything WAY too seriously with his characteristics of an angry stone drains away a lot of the atmosphere the world could have spread and does spread in rare moments.

While it is possible to revisit peviously explored areas, I am sure most people playing this game would have a similar experience as the next person. Darksiders did not leave me wanting more.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2013
												It's easy to draw parallels between Darksiders and the The Legend of Zelda series, it would be no surprise if the developers at Vigil Games created Darksiders as an homage of sorts, especially to Ocarina of Time. Here you have a doppelganger to a basic run-of-the-mill puzzle platformer that we've come to expect from Nintendo: levels with an emphasis on the elements, particularly lava, water, earth, desert, dark, and light, where the only way to complete each level is through a set of challenging obstacles and various enemies, not to mention the cliché "third time's the charm" when it comes to boss fights.Darksiders is a pretty solid game, it has its moments and it has its downfalls but its major defining element is its ability to deliver a well-paced experience with little tedium and monotony, as items that you collect along your journey are spread out enough to feel quite rewarding with an urge to instantly try out your new shiny device, sending you onto the next level only to stumble across another shiny device, ad infinitum. The enemies are also varied enough, and many are unique to their levels, which keeps things interesting.There is a small amount of backtracking, which is heavily expanded on if you wish to collect every item in the game as there is a large incentive to do so. The levels are all well designed and can easily be returned to due to the prevention of the dreaded "point of no return" that many JRPG fans would be familiar with.For me, the highlight of the game was the dialogue, simply because Mark Hamill is such a superb voice actor, as proven by his long standing career as the voice of The Joker. The sound design is pretty wicked and everything sounds as you would expect: ethereal and apocalyptic.The only disadvantages to Darksiders are the myriad of technical issues I had, whether they be glitches with the game's mechanics or bugs preventing certain situations from progressing. One achievement failed to unlock when it was supposed to, and the game crashed no less than four times in one sitting. Twice, due to alt-tabbing and another two times simply because the game bugged out. There are very limited graphical options, sorely missing is a FoV slider as the default FoV is somewhat smothering and isn't suitable for PC standards.Another personal parallel I can draw between this game and The Legend of Zelda is the drastic length of time it took to beat the campaign. I started playing Darksiders in September of 2011, finishing it in February of 2013. Similar to Ocarina of Time, where I decided to take a several year long break due to, you guessed it, the Water Temple.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												TL;DR: Good game, not perfect. Combat is a bit clunky. I preffer combat style of Batman games much more.So, Darksiders. Well, I finished the game, so that's already a big endorsement, however I definitelly wouldn't say that Darksiders is a perfect game.The combat is passable. I seriously don't understand the decision to put dash and block on the same button. That's just stupid. I played the game with a controller and I had huge trouble blocking attacks, either the block wouldn't register, or I dashed. I wish there was no aiming involved when a controller is the perefrable input device (however one of the bosses explicity requires aiming).Boss fights are varied, but I would appreciate the bosses to be slightly easier to figure out. I got frustrated and checked the wiki for one boss fight and one mini-boss fight (then the fight became trivial).The visuals are great. It's a console port, so the textures pretty bad, but the visual presentation definitelly makes up for the grafical fidelity deficiencies.The story is pretty captivating and well written.Overall, I would say that playing this game was a good experience (perhaps a bit too long for what it was). I would recommend this game (especially due to it's age resulting in low price), but I definitelly don't rank it anywhere near the top.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
* PlotDon't want to spoil to much but here's a little about the storyVery fun third person hack & slash game where you play as guy with anger problems that constantly talks as if he needs to take a♥♥♥♥♥♥ His name is War. A battle between Heaven and Hell is waging on earth. You are the balance, sent to earth to return the world years after the apocalypse and restore the world to its original shape. The Destroyer, who is the one responsible for the war between good and evil. You need to defeat him to stop it. The plot was vague to get ahold of in the beginning but gets clearer towards the end. Worth finishing the game for. Story rated 7.5/10* Weapons & CombatCombat reminded me alot of God of War. In Darksiders it was a little too much left mouse button spamming for me though. You had some abilities to attack larger groups for example. Or deal damage over time. I could live with it and play with it. The combat is brutal at times with gory finishing moves. Especially on boss fights. In the stats tab there's also the amount of demon blood you've shed, indicated with gallons. Pointless but unique and fun to show how much you've slain. But I would've love to see something like a stun attack or something that temporarily gave you a shield or strength bonus. There's a couple weapons you will unlock while progressing through the game. For fighting foes, you'll mainly use your trusty sword Chaoseater. Other weapons that you'll unlock will help you to gain access to new places where you can find health upgrades for instance. What lacked in my opinion is gear to collect that add bonuses to health, armor etc. Before realising it I already stuck alot of hours in this game and couldn't stop finishing it. I first finished it on normal and I later tried beating the game on the hardest difficulty (Apocalyptic) as fast as possible and enjoyed playing it again from the start. I had alot of fun with this game. 8/10* Graphics & EnvironmentGraphics look a tad cartoonish but doesn't hurt, you're busy fighting hordes of enemies anyway instead of admiring the graphics. The thing that dragged my attention the ruins of the apocalypse that you got to see as you played through each level. I really loved the matching environment added to the gameplay and story. It was combined very well. Truly, a hell on earth. Lastly the puzzles were fun and often hard to figure out. After beating the puzzles finally, they seemed pretty easy and were even easier to memorize. 9/10Overall: 8/10[/b]

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I'm not a big fan of the slasher/puzzle type games, and Darksiders is no different.  Currently still playing, I find the game way too long - one that should have ended with the defeat of Straga; yet I am still traversing all the levels again looking for the armageddon sword.However, there are many good things worth mentioning about Darksiders (opinions set aside) :- challenging game play, even on easy setting- tonnes of action, puzzles range from easy to difficult- lots of jumping and exploring- great graphics, especially the big bosses- love the premise, heaven/hell join forces to battle evilMinus :- camera clipping issues- sometimes jumps must timed right or you die - leads to frustration- I tried with an 360 controller, and once it is plugged in, the game will only recognize the controller.- would have been nice to include some rpg elements that upgraded the character instead of fight moves- reminded me alot of God of War, especially when climbing on the demon growthThe only reason why I am not recommending this game is because I am not a fan of the slasher/puzzle/jumping around type game.  If you are, then Darksiders is well worth a shot.  If not, pass this one up.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												TL;DR;Another reviewers already describing the good things about darksider. I agree, This is an interesting game. I like it. but you should be aware about the save system. save your game MANUALLY each time you want to quit to main menu or quit the game.======================================================================longer description :Are you sure want to quit to the title screen? All unsaved progress will be lostbut what happened was, it will ALWAYS auto-save your last position in the game and that is really annoying.I've kill Stygian and going to the next "task" ( kill Silitha ). okay, I'm following the yellow icon, passing dry roads. hey, there's vulgrim's serpent holes on the map. I'd better reload my save files and go to nearest vulgrim's serpent holes to silitha's location. okay, I load my latest save file, hey, why I have to fight stygian's little brother again? okay, I quit to the main screen. content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I'm not a big fan of the slasher/puzzle type games, and Darksiders is no different.  Currently still playing, I find the game way too long - one that should have ended with the defeat of Straga; yet I am still traversing all the levels again looking for the armageddon sword.However, there are many good things worth mentioning about Darksiders (opinions set aside) :- challenging game play, even on easy setting- tonnes of action, puzzles range from easy to difficult- lots of jumping and exploring- great graphics, especially the big bosses- love the premise, heaven/hell join forces to battle evilMinus :- camera clipping issues- sometimes jumps must timed right or you die - leads to frustration- I tried with an 360 controller, and once it is plugged in, the game will only recognize the controller.- would have been nice to include some rpg elements that upgraded the character instead of fight moves- reminded me alot of God of War, especially when climbing on the demon growthThe only reason why I am not recommending this game is because I am not a fan of the slasher/puzzle/jumping around type game.  If you are, then Darksiders is well worth a shot.  If not, pass this one up.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is up there with some of my favourite games of all time. I only found out about it recently and it's managed to knock Devil May Cry off it's place as my favourite action/adventure game. It's a shame it never got the attention it deserves but I blame that on the publishers, a little marketing would have gone a long way.Why is it so great? Well, you play as one of the four horsemen, War. You have a reputation of being a fierce and powerful warrior and the game makes a good job of making you feel exactly that.  It makes you feel like you can take on any foe no matter how big, then it gives you a bigger one. Your friends and foes have all heard of you and they have a healthy respect for your power. To put it simply, the game inflates your ego quite nicely.The level design is top notch and each area looks different enough to feel like you are actually on a journey. The fighting style has enough combos and special moves to keep you entertained even on battles that drag on. The bosses are sort of hit and miss for me because they're more like puzzles, once you figure them out, they're quite easy. All in all I'd definitely recommend this game to any fan of the genre. Go buy it, you wont regret it.PS:I know I'll annoy a lot of people by saying this but I'd say Darksiders is better than Devil May Cry and God of War. What? Come at me kinsperson!!

content:
Posted: May 7, 2013
												Darksiders is an action adventure hack'n'slash type of game. You play as War, one of the Four Horsemen. Not  a lot known is about the Horsemen, they're meant to bring the Apocalypse, so this game has an interesting take. The story isn't bad, it's very likable but perhaps a bit forgettable in the end. I felt like I was more enjoying the gameplay than the story itself. You don't really get to know the main character, which makes it harder to connect to him.The gameplay is a blast and very much alike God of War/Devil May Cry. Combat is enjoyable and you have different abilities that you can buy/upgrade. It has a lot of platforming. You have different weapons, some of them can level up. You also use your weapons to solve puzzles. The puzzles are clever and not that hard to solve, a lot of them involves timing. The game also has a few references that you might find familiar. The first real big boss can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥but once you get past you will see that the rest of them are easier. The game is meant to be played with a controller so I can strongly advice you to play with one. However, aiming with ranged weapons are a bit harder with a controller and can complicate things along the way. If you find yourself having trouble with aiming then I suggest that you use your mouse and keyboard when needed. The art style is very fantasy-esque. The game looks good and plays good. The voice acting is pretty okay as well. It's a little outdated by now but it still looks rather pretty. The bosses are huge and they look pretty awesome, it's very satisfying to take them down!I really liked this game and can warmly recommend it, it has a few frustrating parts but none that really ruins the experience. It's not a long game but it's not very short either.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												A fantastic game for all of the people who like hack n' slashes combines with some good ol' fashioned dungeon solving. The plot is pretty in depth; to sum it up, War, the protagonist and also one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse, went down to Earth after the demons of Hell invaded Earth, the angels of Heaven arriving shortly afterwards. The other three horsemen didn't arrive. War stands trial against the Charred Council for dooming the Earth when it wasn't time, essentially. Now War has to revert his crime by going after the 7th Seal, which is in the hands of a corrupted Angel (who I shall not name, as that would spoil some of the plot) who takes the identity of "The Destroyer".Plot aside, this game is great, and it goes on sale quite often. However, there is no shame in picking it up at full price. It's well worth it, in my honest opinion.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Darksiders gives off a very strong Legend of Zelda vibe with explorable enviroments, various different weapons (used to solve puzzles) and a strong storyline. I'll talk about each of these briefly in this review.The graphics in Darksiders are surely not top notch, but they have a style i personally enjoyed greatly. The enviroments are beautiful, the characters (while horribly over the top) are memorable and the soundtrack is decent. Not top notch, but good enough.The gameplay is pretty straightforward. See creature -> swing sword at creature -> creature dies. However, in its simplicity lies its greatest weakness. Fighting enemies quickly loses its appeal, since you don't have to think about it too much. Just swing, dodge attacks from some of the stronger enemies, and you're good to go. You unlock a wealth of alternative and upgradeable weapons throughout the game, but to be honest, all of them fail to improve on what your sword already does. They are, in general, so weak that there's no point using them outside of puzzle solving. Especially once you get certain unlockables, the sword vastly outdoes anything else you'll find, adding to the tedium.Now, the story... The story actually delivers. You are War, arriving on earth to witness to apocalypse in progress, only to be called back in the middle of combat to answer for starting the apocalypse too early. What follows is an entertaining tale of betrayal and redemption (though admittedly, it does not nearly have the substance that Darksiders 2's story had, and the pacing is fairly slow until you start nearing the end). In short, if you're looking for a game that will entertain for a week or so, Darksiders may be worth picking up. While it certainly has its appeal, it won't do more than that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												Before I even start about this review, this game had poetential. It really did. It had a small little cliche "Heaven v.s. Hell" kind of situation even with a cool seven seals addition. But, it seemed to have been completely lost at the fact that this game seems to be a rough copy-paste of Zelda and God of War. I see more similaritys to God of War than Zelda (I've played more God of War then Zelda) But that still doesn't excuse it. Not only does War have a similar character look to Kratos, his move set seems to be the same as Kratos'. Not to mention the same reptitive gameplay as God of War, fighting the same enemy over and over. The "Press E to do a special finiser" is taken from God of War as well. Not to mention the boss fights take after it as well. Going as far as to even use three color orbs for "Currency, Health, and Wrath" Which any fellow God of War player may have noticed from that game as "Health, Magic, and Rage". Not to mention that this wasn't exactly the best port to PC and that you'd need experience to play it with Keyboard and mouse. There's been worse, but this is still easier to play with controller. The aiming for throwing items is sloppy, and kind of hard to use. Seriously, if you want a better time and game, go buy the God of War games. Don't waste four dollars on the sale for this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I heard quite a lot of good rumors about this game, but when I started I was bit skeptical. I didn't know that the game actually takes place in modern world, I thought that it would be fantasy settings, nor I am fan of bending traditional mythology. But it wasn't that bad after all, can't say the same about Thor movie which ran on TV 2 days before I wrote this. God, it was awful and not only because of lot of lore inaccuracies...Basicly it's hack&slash with some rpg elements. You kill enemies who will kindly hand you their souls and for these you buy items, moves and few spell. Since it is a simple port UI is bit limited, there is about 6 item in game but you can only slot 3, and if you want to use different ones you have to open inventory drag them to quick-slots, which is cumbersome. Also you can't cast spell with a single key you have to use two >.< . I tried playing with the controller but I quickly came back to good old mouse&keyboard, since in my opinion it's easier to play this way, I found it hard to execute dashing attack with controller not to mention aiming is much quicker with mouse. Story is decent even though it was mildly confusing for me until certain point. Also at first I thought they used names Abbadon and Destroyer simply because they couldn't thought about more cool sounding and fitting names, since both means the same,  but that cleared up near the end of the game. But well, if it was supposed to be the twist, then it wasn't. Anyway, after my skepticism faded I had quite a good time with the game. And I can honestly recommend it.PS: Warning for achievement hunters! The game has problems with steam achievements and you may not get ones you normally should. To avoid grief, save often and if you don't get achievement, restart steam and launch the game. You have to do this every time if you want to avoid "not getting achievemnts" issue. I missed few, which normally can't be missed myself because of this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												Imagine God of War, except with 300% more puzzles and 200% less combat. This game has incredibly tedious puzzles paired up with repetitive combat. You'll come to learn that enemies lack dynamic mechanics to where it's nearly just a hack and slash and puzzle game thrown together. Throughout the game you will always find yourself doing puzzles more often than you are fighting enemies, and when you do fight enemies its the same 2 enemies reskinned. Did I mention that the story is just packed with loads and loads of puzzles? The game also gives you 5 items to do said puzzles and you will use all 5 throughout each area when you get them all. However you can only hotkey 3 of the 5 and have to go inside the ingame inventory to hotkey the other item just to have to re-hotkey the item you just un-hotkeyed to use the item you needed for the last puzzle. It had a lot of potential with story but the story just felt dragged out and the only reason why i play the game is because I feel like I'm getting closer to the end, but then they just throw in more and more paths filled with more and more puzzles. I'm 12 hours into the game and I finally felt like I was nearing the end boss when they threw in a completely new zone without ever being mentioned in the game prior and gave me a new item that lead to an incredibly boring fight and seemingly more boring puzzle mechanic. Overall it really isn't as good of a game that you hoped it to be and it I don't even want to complete the game because of how much of a chore it feels like.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Darksiders is a novel idea that has too many glaring bugs and glitches that weigh it down. The "Black Throne Elevator Glitch" is a more immediate example that comes to mind in regards to how the game can force you to completely restart due to a glitch the community has known about for years. Indeed, if you are a completionist, save frequently, and save multiple files. Despite having an interesting premise and some above-average gameplay, Darksiders has simply not aged well. If you can catch the title on sale like I did (for around $2), then I would say that it is certainly worth the price - just keep in mind that it can be a mess at times.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												This is an almost 8 year old game. And however, it stands out as one of the best of its genre.I played first when it came out, and my expectations were low, as I thought this was going to be a cheap God of War clone. It turned out I was wrong: combat was simple but satisfying, landscapes were imaginative and vibrant, and the story, while not deserving an Oscar, was mildly interesting. But what won me over was the puzzles. You see, this is in some way a Metroidvania: you can revisit previous locations with abilities you gain during your playthrough in order to get to new areas. The ways you get to use your new gear are sometimes not straightforward and there are more than a couple of clever puzzles in the game. Yes, many abilities we have seen in other games, like Portal, but when you copy things that work and are well implemented in the gameplay like this game does, then it's totally forgivable. Some people I know claim this is the best Zelda title ever, and I agree. Besides War, the main character is a total badass. When I revisited the game for my second playthrough a month or so ago, I tried to temper my expectations thinking 7 years have gone by and maybe it wasn´t going to hold up well. How wrong was I. Despite, the comparatively low polygon count of the models and backgrounds, the choice of colors and the exceptional design make them look great (this is the old tech vs art design debate), the combat without being as refined as DmC is responsive and satisfying, and puzzles and exploration are as good as ever. A sign of the quality of the game is that the company that bought the rights to the title is going to release  a 1080p/60fps version soon. Obviously if you have an average PC you should be able to play it at that resolution with no issues.Do yourself a favor and play this!

The game does look great, but it is not the hack and slash I was hoping for, meaning I wanted to just mindlessly kill stuff. The only real challenge to the game is poor level layout.In all, if you would like a GoW experience without the GoW... anything really, you are in for a treat.3/10

												Darksiders is a masterpiece. The puzzles and game mechanics are almost as good as in Zelda (although not quite ...), but what really pushes it ahead of other Zelda clones and even some of the Zelda games is the fantastic setting and characters. I loved how beautifully desolate the world was and how they focused on a small number of powerful NPCs to reinforce the desolation. It made perfect sense to only interact with demonic lords, angels and powerful magical creatures, because on the post-apocalyptic earth everyone else dies fast.

If you're one of the few people lucky enough to get a copy that doesn't require a 3rd party controller emulator, then you should pride yourself on falling into a rare demographic. content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I've tried to get into this game on two separate occasions now, and it just doesn't hold my attention. It feels a lot like God of War, but it's not quite as exciting. The abilities you gain along the way aren't all that useful from what I've encountered, and you'll probably find yourself button-mashing your way through most fights. When gameplay is less than fantastic, I usually turn to the story to save the experience. The story seems interesting, but the stoic main character is not really a protagonist that elicits any sympathy from me, and I feel no sense of satisfaction when I further the plot. I'm honestly struggling to write this review because I just don't remember much of the game. It's not bad, and, if you've never played God of War or even Devil May Cry or the Batman games, you'll probably enjoy it. Otherwise, I would pass on this. It's just kind of "meh."

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												     This game is a masterpiece with incredible art, amazing sound and excellent gameplay.  For the PC however, it does not run well.  I've seen similar problems on many forums, that the game is not optimized for PC and so runs much, much higher than recommended 3MB of RAM and suggested Radeon graphcs card.     My computer has four times the necessary RAM and a graphics card that is more than double the power of the listed and still the cutscenes stutter, audio goes out and has all the symptoms of a very low end PC running a very high-end game.  My computer runs games like Crysis and Skyrim with little effort and yet cannot run this game. :P     I have not had this issue with the second Darksiders on PC, just this one.  I'm not sure if there is an intended fix for this but, I would not recommend purchasing this for PC, play it on Xbox 360 or your PS3 (if you have either of those) instead.1/10 for PC - 10/10 for any other system. ;)

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												It really, really, really pains me to tell you not to buy this game. I want to enjoy it--I do enjoy it, in fact--but I cannot recommend it because it constantly crashes to desktop. I originally tried to play this game with a Keyboard and Mouse, but I gave up early on when the controls became much too cumbersome. I got a 360 controller a week ago as an early Xmas present, and decided to reinstall it because it would be perfect with my new controller!When the game is good, it's a fun romp toward a bizarre Post-Apocalyptic wasteland populated by angels and demons, and you play a Kratos-lite a**hole bent on revenge for some or other betrayal that I can't remember. Long story short, it's got a little bit of Zelda mixed in with dicing an endless supply of demon fodder with your assortment of oversized steel weapons.Unfortunately, not long after reinstalling it, I discovered that it would crash to desktop every time I played, anytime between 5 minutes--and sometimes less than that, even!--to an hour. The game is about as bad as a Bethesda title on Launch Day, but it has little to motivate players from investing the patience to complete it (I'm only playing it because I have nothing else to play at the moment and am trying to clean up my Steam backlog a little bit. I figure I've made it this far, I might as well finish it).That it has little to motivate players doesn't mean that the game is bad--I'd give it a decent 7.5-8/10 if it didn't constantly crash. And the severity of the issue is compounded by a terrible save system that is governed by your entry into an area, and it will not usually save what you did in an area unless you reach a scripted monster fight/checkpoint, or move to a new area. Picking up items (with the exception of Armageddon blade pieces) will not trigger the save system, either. So if you grab that obscure Abyssal Armor piece and the game crashes--even if you saved manually upon acquiring it, you will have to do all that again when you restart the game.I have scoured forums online searching for a fix or workaround, but I haven't found one that applies to my machine (I was able to play The Witcher 3 on medium, and this game runs perfectly--except for the crashing--on high settings).As it stands, do not buy this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												When a game is good, I quit a round of playing it because I feel sated and find I had enough fun for now and should do something else.When quite a bit of frustration and boredom builds up and makes me quit the game, I can not call the game a good game but only an OK gave.When at some point I seriously consider either uninstalling the game because I just don't want to endure some BS anymore or search for a cheat online to get past a certain point [spoileri]Sandwormlevel...[/spoileri], the only thing I can say about the game is that it sucks.So, in this case, the game sucks.It's story may be good, the combat may feel great, it may be really fun to sometimes just slash up enemies, but there repeatedly are situations where I feel myself getting really annoyed.At some points I looked into guides to do a certain part, at one point I even seriously searched for cheat codes, after I died several times in the same BS part and had to endure a video sequence which I couldn't skip and a minute of annoying gameplay over and over again.I would have PAID for a cheat code that allowed me to fly.In the levels where you have to ride AND shoot at the same time the controls are just horrendous, you can EITHER aim, OR evade the enemies OR control your horse, but you somehow would have to do everything at the same time, which just doesn't work at all.When you aim you ride into the direction you aim, resulting in you suiciding right into the enemy.When you try to ride while looking back your horse will just turn around most of the time.The controls are just terrible.I feel that the game producers have not even the slightest idea how to make a good game.To me it seems they wanted to achieve a long playtime, but they did by having you run far distances and by forcing you to play the game twice in order to uncover every secret item.Larger enemies are hard to beat not because they do anything special, they will just do a ton of damage and sometimes even kill you right away without you being able to do anything about it.That, dear devs, is not how to make a good game.A good game makes fights interesting and increases playtimre by having the fights against bigger enemies last longer and by giving the enemies attacks that have to be avaded but won't cost the player a major part of their HP if failed to evade.Sadly the way Darkiders works is that you will suddenly die to high damage attacks because you can barely or not at all evade them.Darksiders will have you face enemies with projectiles that you can't evade and which will sometimes do enough damage to kill you right away.This will happen repeatedly.And you will have to go into the same fight over and over again and you will be killed over and over again.If the part is supposed to be even harder to beat, there will just be two of those enemies put into a room with you.Yes, you can quick save, but that is complete utter b***s***.When you quick save in a difficult part and die, the quick save is lost.Nope, no saving and duing a short part to save again and so on.You die, save is lost.I couldn't get a bigger punch in the face.I also don't have the feeling that I beat the game by having "skill", I beat it by repeatedly abusing an item to stun large enemies so they won't kill me with one or two attacks.That, by the way, makes at least me quit the game in frustration and boredom.

												Do not buy this game, here's why:Bad port. Clunky controls, limited graphic options, often awkward camera and my personal favorite a dead mouse. Obviously this port was made for quick cash in.You will run into a technical problems. Once you try to turn on the game it welcomes you with black screen which requires you to delete some files from game directory or restart steam. Achievements won't unlock until you restart steam and you are never certain if you are going to unlock them or not. Save file might dissapear when you're half through a game.Sound freezes for no reason durring cutscene.Other than technical failures it feels like some soul-less executive in a expensive suit came into a game dev office, ditched five most successful games over last 5 years and ordered to frankenstein it together because it's guaranteed to sell. It doesn't have soul of it's own and often feels stale and boring compared to other games. It rips off portal, god of war, legend of zelda and adds nothing new. It'll fit perfectly in my buyers remorse category.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												You can say all you want but in the end the game's combat is little better than bland.The common enemies can just be chopped to tiny bits using AoE attacks and the bigger ones force you to use one single tactic to beat them. Of course if you love doing the same thing over and over then by all means, this is the game for you. I quit at the Tiamat bossfight and let me explain why; in this bossfight you're at a high tower and this oversized bat fires fireballs at you. Obviously since it's flying around you can't hit it so you have to throw a bomb at it, then wait for it to get close to a torch so you can get the bomb to ignite by first hitting the torch with your throwing glaive and then hitting that you threw at Tiamat (they stick), all the while that creature is constantly shooting fireballs at you and constantly flying away from the torch. But again, if you like to follow very use very very specific tactics in bossfights with quick time events that don't feel rewarding in any way while losing feels as punishing as it could ever, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												A great story, with good characters, almost ruined by a game.I want to love this game.  The story is engaging, I keep saying 'I want to know what happens next.'  You are a horseman of the apocalypse, which for some reason in the universe of this game are the guardians of the balance between heaven and hell.  Well someone messed that up, destroyed all mankind, and framed the rider War for screwing everything.  You are War, find the party responsible, make them pay.  Lots of twists and turns on that path, you'll honestly like a few demons, give others the finger, and laugh with glee while gunning down angels.  The visuals are impressive, remember all the World of Warcraft art with all the highly detailed armor?  Remember how that game looks nothing like that art?  This one does.  This looks like that.  This is the game that wanted to be visually.  Very pretty to look at, glorious in motion especially on PC without any framerate loss.There are two problems.  First, they decided they wanted to make a puzzle platformer.  Wonderful bits of swordplay are interrupted by seriously overly long puzzle sections of tedius boredom.  Hope you like backtracking!  Seriously, you are forced to backtrack an absurd amount, and sometimes the path to where you need to be gets very confusing.  Prepare for lots of frustration before you get to the next stabby bit.Second, they decided they wanted to add tons and tons of stuff.  We're talking hey!  Giant sword!  Cool, now give him a killer boomerang thing!  Awesome, but how about a gun?  Can we give him a gun?  Awesome!  But you know every good hero has a grappling gun, give him one of those!  Coded!  Great!  Now hey... There's this game called portal, maybe we should play with portals too?  BAM!  Portal gun added!  Sooo....  Let's drop the bass, give this guy a literal warhorn too!  A little odd but, done!  Now quests for collectables that require backtracking to every single game section after you acquire all this stuff!  Not to say how annoying it is to try to use it all in combat.The controls are a little iffy, the camera likes to do perspective changes while you are trying to do percise platform jumping, which is a bit maddening.  Thankfully the game is very forgiving of the inevitable falls into endless pits, a small health penalty and puts you right back where you were this time knowing what the camera is about to do to you mid jump.  For the non platform sections?  Controls work fine.  With two exceptions.1.  The game really needs a 360 controller.  The complicated mess of all the STUFF they want you to do is incredibly awkward on a keyboard.2.  The range weapon controls are beyond terrible.  Going into aim mode makes you turn slower than molasses, and you need to hit things moving at full speed.  Makes you very thankful to get back to bashing things with your giant sword.Then there is the purchase new combos option, which most tend to fall into two categories.  Too time consuming and or difficult to trigger mid combat, or way too easy to tigger mid combat so you're always going moves that take you in a direction you didn't want to go.  Thankfully the devs made the game smart enough not to let you fly off a cliff because you were doing a combo.  So go for the ledge fights, just keep well clear of the jump button.One more note is stability.  The windows port is known for crashing.  But there is no pattern to this, all gamers report crashes at different spots with really no perdictibility.  In my experience I've had something like 6 game crashes in 13  hours.  I would say 3 were alt-tab related.  I also had a 4 hour flawless session that spawned multiple levels.  So be prepared, you will lose progress time to time.The recommend yes/no system is a bit too limiting, I'd put this game at 75%.  Not enough to tell everyone to go get it, but if you want lots of puzzles with your hack and slash then pick it up.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Who is this Game For?==================People that relate this game to Zelda have no idea what they are talking about. If I was to make a comparison, the closest game Darksiders resembles is Force Unleashed II. There is not one puzzle in this whole game as far as I could tell in my play through. The game always told you exactly what to do, and if there was something that could be a puzzle in a room, the auto-camera makes sure to zoom onto objects and paths that need to be explored, eliminating any thought process that might otherwise be needed. It’s a straight up hack-n-slash. If that's what you are into, get this title.Is it good?=================The boring linear gameplay, and almost no character progression, does not exactly have a recipe for a winner. Does it have any problems?========================This is a very poorly done port. Horrible controls, no graphics options and the game has a lot more issues. You'll need to check out http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Darksiders if you have any problems. Final Thoughts!====================A laughably boring main character, uninteresting plotline, and a steep learning curve for combat doesn’t help sell the game much. The boss fights are entertaining and the voice acting isn't a marvel. If you could enjoy, say, God of War, but without the storyline, characters, or great voice acting, then you could probably enjoy this game.

												Pros: - Amazing story (at least what you can get to)- The few boss battles I got to play were fun- Makes you feel pretty badass- Voice acting was greatNeutral:- Graphics are nothing great, but not awfulCons:- Lots of forced camera movement- Gimmicky enemies- Achievements are broken - Save files get corrupted/don't work/go missing etc etc,Don't bother picking this up, the devs have abandonded it in it's broken state to throw out a remaster (why would I bother playing that if this is so messed up?). Collectibles missing (but gone from the world like they were collected). Achievements rarely unlock after the first two, which would kill it for most people.

												Minus a couple of slow points, I enjoyed it.Pros--The story was fun and different--The protagonist's character arc was a level lazer beam, but he's a bad-♥♥♥, so...--The settings were not colorful, but they matched the situation well--Music was decent--Voice acting was good--Many of the puzzles were challenging to solve and implement the solutionCons--Had some interface issues where if I alt-tabbed, the game would usually crash--Had 20 earned achievements not unlock--Controls were clearly based upon using a controller instead of keyboard/mouse--THQ and Vigil games are no more as of 25 January 2013, so there will be no more support for this game.Depends on your point of view--Level design reminded me a lot of Metroid--Shamelessly copied a lot of other games

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Who is this Game For?==================People that relate this game to Zelda have no idea what they are talking about. If I was to make a comparison, the closest game Darksiders resembles is Force Unleashed II. There is not one puzzle in this whole game as far as I could tell in my play through. The game always told you exactly what to do, and if there was something that could be a puzzle in a room, the auto-camera makes sure to zoom onto objects and paths that need to be explored, eliminating any thought process that might otherwise be needed. It’s a straight up hack-n-slash. If that's what you are into, get this title.Is it good?=================The boring linear gameplay, and almost no character progression, does not exactly have a recipe for a winner. Does it have any problems?========================This is a very poorly done port. Horrible controls, no graphics options and the game has a lot more issues. You'll need to check out http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Darksiders if you have any problems. Final Thoughts!====================A laughably boring main character, uninteresting plotline, and a steep learning curve for combat doesn’t help sell the game much. The boss fights are entertaining and the voice acting isn't a marvel. If you could enjoy, say, God of War, but without the storyline, characters, or great voice acting, then you could probably enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Darksiders is, without exception, the longest linear game I have completed. Without mucking about trying to 100% the secret items (including what I understand to be an entirely overpowered suit of armor), I completed the game in 20 hours. With no substantial exception, that twenty hours was spent navigating a series of single-branched corridors and single-solution puzzles that felt simultaneously inorganic and unfulfilling to navigate. War is a hulking, grumpy nephilim who fancies oversized armor and weapons, action-film dialogue, and violence as the answer to every problem. Which is all of it perfectly fine- the game has an aesthetic which kept me playing along despite its derth of challenge or mechanical variety (not to mention the unfortunate amount of retreading that must be done as part of normal gameplay). But if you are not sustained by the aesthetic- and I only completed the game out of a combined masochistic streak and desire to learn more about bad video game design- Darksiders will quickly lose your attention, as War's repetoire of attack skills is limited to attacking, countering, dodging, and little else, with the vast majority consisting of mashing the X button until the enemy has either died from damage or can be executed by a special move that never varies and often takes substantially longer to perform than a death by damage would. The puzzles are generally straightforward and are less jigsaws and more mazes with a handful of steps that must be completed in a precise order before the player can proceed. Very rarely do these prove taxing intellectually, but they are often taxing of one's patience, as the solution generally becomes obvious long before the player can realize it through a series of platforming obstacles and stiffly targetted bomb-throwing or shooting tasks. The very BEST that Darksiders has to offer is in its boss fights, several of which force the player to quickly analyze the arena and boss itself to determine the method by which the boss can be defeated (there is generally only one method). Some of these drag on with the shear number of blows that the bosses sustain before being defeated, with no change in difficulty during the repetition of the fight mechanics. The first and final bosses proved to be the most challenging and satisfying. In sum, I can't recommend this game. There are a large number of superior games of this genre, mechanically and in terms of story, and $20 will go much farther with them.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Darksiders draws inevitable comparisons to Zelda and god of War. Its a shame that it is never as smart as the first or as satisfying as the second.The combat in bland, simplistic, overused and repetitive. You cant properly mix weapons in combos, in fact, most combos are 1 button sequences like: X, XX or XXX. If you wana be a pro try holding X for a sec. Yeah...Off course sometimes you also have to dodge, but considering how much the enemies telegraph you their attacks I can say you almost have time to check your email. And don't let me start on the "finishing" animations, so frequent and repetitive that got me tired of them after 1 hour of game.Overall the flow of the game is very contrived. A lot of it feels like filler, especially the underdeveloped platform segments. To make worst, most puzzles feel uninspired and tedious, riped off directly from zelda games, but without the same level of polish in its execution.There is constantly something gating your progress that don't feel like it was needed and the ways you solve problems always sound like they took triple the time they should have taken.Its not terrible, for sure, and has semblances of being a fun game on a few moments, but on the long run is boring, which for a game is almost a worst sin.

Not only can you not play it at a higher resolution but you must disable every security feature which include any active anti-virus, maleware protection and your firewall. It doesn't matter what your computer specs are there are no way to alter or reduce the demand of physical memory this game allocates to your system. In some cases if your save game file becomes too large it won't load, if you stop in a spot right before a boss fight and enter, it will freeze. If you try asnd summon either the watcher or Ruin your steed, it will freeze at times. This game is far too buggy and I regret buying it in the first place and of course it seems that steam is in no hurry to make any fixes to their products, as usual. So you can forget a fix in the future at any rate and the developers are under a new name and most likely will not provide any support for this game as it is a only a few years old.

Besides aiming mechanics and perspective it has everything up to and including chests, grappling hook, bottles, masks and even a shadow Link battle. The game takes it upon itself to install these things to your main partition without asking you though. I enjoyed the comic. It's pretty cheesy but then so is the game. I'm also a sucker for supplemental material like this.

												   I absolutely love this game. Not only is it based on the Bible but you're one of the horsemen. The gameplay mechanics are awesome and the story very well writen. content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Darksiders 1. probably one of my favorite games. And with nvdia gtx 660, this game has been reborn on PC. It is totally playable with mouse and keyboard, but i prefer the xbox style controller. This game is an all-round thumbs up. perfect hack/slash, with great RPG elements. The game allows you to explore to a degree without being led off the story. My opinion, its better than 2. Though i love death, i prefer this game.  i recommend both! get this game for xbox or playstation. its a great game. but the devs arent making any effort to fix the achievement problem nor game performance for PC. game runs fine. just isnt tuned properly for PC.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Darksiders had a lot of potential, but the series doesn’t fulfill it until the sequel. Yes, the environment and characters are awesome, but this game doesn’t deserve the praise it has gotten. Why? Because it fails at being the one thing a game has to be: fun. As other reviewers have said, the longer the game goes the more tedious it becomes. The fights and exploration become long and boring and the game becomes a chore. Pass and buy Darksiders II instead.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												It's like the Legend of Zelda and God of War had a baby. Excellent combat, although the camera gets extremely wonky at times, interesting story with a few plot twists thrown in for good measure, excellent and varied boss battles, except for a certain teleporting wench that we won't talk about ever again, interesting puzzles that are difficult enough to keep you engaged, but not too hard so as to leave you stuck for 20 minutes staring at the same wall, and the best part? Unlike God of War, where the main protag tries too hard to be a badass and ends up being a redundantly despicable piece of scum, the protag here is actually a genuine badass, who doesn't murder things simply for having their toes in his way. 8.5/10Also, just a heads up, this games setting and story heavily twists Abrahamic religions, so if you're sensitive about consorting with demons and pulling angels wings off with your bare hands and then tossing their impaled bodies around like ragdolls, you may want to skip out on this one.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Game is OK, the backtracking killed it for me. With no way to know which areas you need to go back for collectibles you're gonna be spending a lot of time wandering aimlessly unless you follow a guide.This game needed some serious QoL changes. The fast travel sucks. Not only do you have to walk all the way to a a waypoint but after you activate the waypoint, you also gotta run through an alternate dimension area to get where you want to go. Why? This is just a waste of time.Why are there so few hotkeys for your equipment? There's about 5-6 tools you need to use to roam the world but only 3 of those can be hotkeyed at any time.Why is there no way to hastily leave a previously completed dungeon? I went into the Twilight Cathedral in search of upgrades I didn't collect. After about 5 minutes I decided I couldn't be arsed to find my way out again. Closed the game and uninstalled on the spot.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												This isn't really a bad game (it's actually a competent game), but it's such a generic-feeling action adventure game that it's really not worth your time when there are far more interesting games to play.  Story and enemy design is astoundingly boring, and combat is just mashing the attack button, occasionally using a magic spell if you get surrounded or turning into an invincible badass for 15 seconds once you build up enough charge.   Every once in a while things are made interesting with getting a horse or a huge cannon for a bit, and exploring hard to find areas is fun.The puzzles are just awful late in the game.  You get a portal gun which is a direct copy of Valve's Portal Gun, except the puzzles are frustrating and not intuitive.  Half the time you don't know what you need to be doing with the gun, or where you need to go.God of War is far superior to this, and although I haven't played many games of this type, I'm sure there are better options.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Before I go into depth I want to specify that I did use a gamepad for this game - I strongly recommend using one and would go so far as to say to skip this title if you don't have one. It's a console port, guys. Darksiders is a game that wears its inspirations on its sleeve famously, and to a ridiculous degree. When you're traveling through a Legend of Zelda-style dungeon solving puzzles with a Portal Device, you know you're not playing a game that's focusing on being particularly innovative. That's fine, it doesn't do it does particularly well though. The dungeons, level design wise, are all threadbare. Puzzles never get more complicated than "get past the obstruction using the item you got in that dungeon", platforming reaches its maximum amount of complexity 20 minutes into the game, and exploration is limited because despite the expansive levels, there's very few optional areas. You're taken in a very roundabout, but ultimately linear, path and led by the nose from start to finish.Combat doesn't fair any better - it has all the tools to play well, but the way it's executed is an absolute mess. Even the Counter, the quintessential "up yours" high-risk high-reward move that's been a staple of decent hack n slash games for over a decade, will often be cancelled and interrupted because it doesn't interrupt a good deal of enemy attacks - seemingly at random.The moveset cops a lot of flak for its simplicity, but once you unlock the full movesets for each weapon and supplement each weapon's combos with another weapon (you can even switch out your sidearm and combo them into each other) you can get a nice amount of combat variation going on. Design doesn't support that, though, since the game has the a conceptually moronic weapon leveling system that strongly discourages using more than one weapon - the difference between weapon levels is more than just palpable. Add to that that combos have no impact on anything whatsoever.At its best, it plays like a more forgiving Devil May Cry, but mostly it plays like a more brainless God of War and it suffers for that heavily. The whole lack of finesse seeps into every corner of the game. They're terrified you'll play it wrong, or will look in the wrong direction for more than a second - puzzles will constantly be interrupted by those infuriating drawn-out mini-cutscenes which point out what you're meant to do, the Watcher is used as a device to call your attention to something that's already flashing, and many more examples. One particularly egregious example has you explore a small environment for four challenge portals, that as well as having icons on the map and having giant beams shoot up into the sky, even have Eye of Sauron-like icons on top of the beams just to be extra sure that you don't actually have to explore.Darksiders has all the tools and capability to play well, but it adamantly refuses to. On a more positive note, the environments are absolutely fantastic, I was personally fond of the character design  - despite my usual complete distaste for giant pauldrons - due to just how well done it is, and it has some of the best flashy particle use I've ever seen.War as a lead is bland, but he isn't antagonizing or unlikeable. The supporting cast is similarly lacking in character but inoffensive (with the exception of Samael and the Watcher, who were both pretty enjoyable). The story isn't particularly interesting, but isn't grating.It's an incredibly pretty game (despite the very noticeable lack of anti-aliasing in a game with so many sharp edges), and if you're looking for a stylish hack n slash and are willing to overlook a few design issues that drag it down, then check it out. I wouldn't outright recommend it to anybody that isn't looking for that particular type of game, though.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I really wish this were better than it is.Negative first (since you're reading this to know why I voted it down)It's a fairly shoddy console port. Controller-oriented menus, few graphical options, shoddy mouse and keyboard control. With a controller, it handles decently, whereas some battles are literally impossible to complete with the mouse and keyboard controlsIt has both fatal [CTD] and non-fatal [restart from checkpoint] bugs that are quite frustrating to say the leastPoor level and mechanic design. These vary from small and numerous (issues with engine-based input/action/animation lag, poor mechanical decisions, getting stunlocked to death, innappropriate or inadiquate checkpoint locations, etc.) all the way to compounded and quit-worthy (I stopped when I reached a miniboss that could take half my health in one hit, did an attack that covered 95% of the arena, and would knockdown for a second or even third invariably fatal hit after the first connected)A feeling of "Jack of all trades, master of none," it tries to do too much. It's a combo-heavy hack 'n slash with puzzles and platforming, an RPGesque level-up system, and collectables that are actually key to survival. There is so much that you forget half of it even exists, so there were battles it took me an hour to figure out because they relied upon a mechanic I forgot about. None of the above are fully polished, and there are many hiccups, especially in the platforming and puzzling, where little to no direction is given, and the level design is not good enough to guide you through naturally.This game is like a tutorial on how NOT to make boss fights. Take heed, game designers - these are inventive bosses with some of the most abysmal execution and unfair feeling losses I have ever seen in a game. They're not outright broken most of the time, they're just so unfair or punishing for the tiniest mistake that they echo the Famicom era of game design - play it over and over until you memorize it and time every move perfectly.On the plus side:The models and art, including the voice and music portions are nicely polished most of the time. Cutscenes were well done, the characters are well acted, and animations are polished. The story is fairly trite, but I expected no less
