content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Darksiders is perhaps a good game, but by no means a great one. However, this poor port from the consoles to the PC is perhaps the most damaging aspect of the game. So damaging that I find myself unwilling to endure it long enough to finish it. To start things off, a Windows update from early June of 2013 has made any video/CGI portion of the game unbearable. The top half of all of these sequences is nothing, but black. While many are quick to blame MS for this bug, I am not. The reason being that every single game I own, older and newer than Darksiders, is unaffected. Only Darksiders is affected, which leads me to put most of the blame squarely at the feet of the now defunct developer. And the grand-daddy of them all are the controls. They are downright terrible for the PC version. In the beginning you can easily manage to customize your mouse and keyboard in a way that makes the controls bearable, but as you progress throughout the game and gain new abilities you will find yourself agonizing over trying to find a new way to customize you controls all over again in a way that will work. Also, Steam offers only partial controller support for the game, so the only way to use one effectively is the tedious programming through a third-party program. Perhaps if the gameplay was a little more in-depth rather than hack and slash then it would be worth it to put up with these flaws. Alas, it is not. Other features that seem to be lacking is the freedom to move around the world, and the lack of an expansive world at that. I never finished the game, but considering that the game is just only 12-15 hours long, and that I got a quarter of the way through it, I would think that it would begin to open up in some more ways. If it does open up later then I doubt you will have much time to delight in it. There are some bright spots, however. Much of what this game takes after is The Legend of Zelda franchise. The puzzles, the dungeon-like settings, and whatnot are all there. But the game doesn't do much else to differentiate itself in a positive fashion. The puzzles are too simplistic (much more than the recent 3-D Zelda games), and the world is not nearly as expansive as Twilight Princess or even Ocarina of Time. It may sound unfair to compare Darksiders to the granddaddy of all adventures franchise, let alone Ocarina of Time, the highest rated game in video game history. But if one is to compete then they must offer something exclusive or something better. The only areas where it pulls it off is the secondary-attack weapons. But other than that there is nothing but cheap QTE-like finishing moves, and tons of blood to cover-up its obviously dated gameplay, even for the standards of 2010 (the year of release). The lack of decent controls on PC, the video problems on PC, the dated mechanics, and the lack of an open and compelling world doomed this game from potential greatness to okay.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												To say "not recommended" isn't necessarily the vibe of what I want to give from this review. Ultimately my sentiments would lean more toward a neutral response, but "not recommended" captures my intention more than recommended does. I wouldn't recommend this game, not because it's a bad game, but because it's not a good game. It's mediocre. It may appeal to people who thought Zelda was too difficult, but that's about the extent that my recommendation goes.Ultimately the biggest problem with the game is that it's way too easy. I played it on normal mode, so naturally I don't expect the monsters to be anything special, but that's not the kind of difficulty that I'm talking about. I mean that the puzzles are way too easy and the dungeons are way too linear. Perhaps I shouldn't compare it too much to Zelda, but that and God of War seem to be what most people compare it to. I can definitely see the inspiration of Zelda on the game, but they've dumbed that down into only a handful of dungeons that are extremely simple to navigate through and beat. There are a couple of decent puzzles that leave you with a sense of accomplishment, but once again comparing it to the quality of Zelda, it leaves something to be desired.Most of these easy puzzles are accomplished by gimmick weapons that are found in the dungeon that you'll find yourself using it the most. Generally these weapons serve little practical purpose outside of the dungeon they're found, though there are a few exceptions. One such gimmick item is one that greatly resembles the gun from Portal. When I first saw it I thought "awesome, I can portal around everywhere now. What a great idea!" But unfortunately that excitement was stifled by the realization that you can only use the gun on a handful of orange circles. It was kind of cool going around with it, but they overused the gimmick in the dungeon to the point that it felt tedious, and they only used it a couple of times outside of the dungeon to get little secret items. The horse, Ruin, was also like this. The horse was cool when you could use him, but War is limited to using the horse in only certain areas. I had hoped that a game about a horseman would feature more horse, but the game is pretty close to the end by the time you even get him.The power glove item that lets you smash the blue crystals was neat since you could use it as a weapon, but it really wasn't that great of a weapon either. For the most part I found myself only using the sword and the crossblade (the boomerang) in battles, and the latter was still pretty weak, but could help subdue certain enemies. I almost never used the wraith skills (though they may prove more helpful in Apocalyptic difficulty). The chaos form was pretty helpful, though perhaps it made the game too easy. The story is one of the areas where the game does shine. I don't want to give too much away, but it is pretty unique, and perhaps it's the only thing I really liked about the game. The characters are decent and likeable too, though admittedly the names can be a little confusing at first. The swordplay isn't bad either, though it can be tedious at times. Maybe I had an issue with this because I never used my wrath items or other weapons, but the sword just worked better than the rest of them. Your character controls a lot like a character from World of Warcraft, which works pretty well. I only have two gripes with the movement. The first is that when you're targeted onto a character and you use your dash move, it moves your character relative to the screen rather than relative to your character. This leads to your character darting toward an attacking enemy rather than dashing to the side periodically. It would have been more intuitive if it had been done relative to the character. The second gripe is that the horseplay can be a little clunky as well, though this is a relatively small problem.The game suffers from bugs as well. Perhaps this is more situational to the player, but during my runthrough of the game it crashed between five and ten times. It wasn't super bad, but it was highly annoying. Additionally, sometimes when you're climbing on that demonvine stuff and you want to jump to another piece, it won't let your character do it, and you have to try again. Similarly, often after you land one such jump your character will be stuck there unable to move. Another glitch I ran into is that often when you try to summon your horse, it will summon him for a second and then your character will immediately unsummon him, which can be pretty annoying. One final bug that I noticed was that sometimes the music would  partially cut out and the game would sound hollow. A restart fixes this, but it's still annoying. These bugs may just be limited to a few people, though, so I don't necessarily calculate them into my real recommendation, but they're worth noting.Exploration felt pretty shallow. There were some neat areas to explore, like one area called the Drowning Pool, but for the most part there wasn't much to explore since the game is so linear. A lot of the exploration in the game relied on going back to old areas with new abilities, which was kind of tedious since it relied on backtracking rather than new challenges. It was kind of cool opening up old areas, but if you don't remember exactly where they were, then you have to go through the whole ordeal of the dungeon again, which proved to be banal, though the puzzles were precompleted by you. At least there was some sense of exploration, but as I said, what was there felt shallow.The soundtrack to the game is fine too. Nothing to get too excited over, but not necessarily bad either. Just fine. And the game could have expanded more on a certain subplot featuring a certain dapper undead, too. At least it was there at all, but the game didn't really do anything with it. It could have been awesome, but it was just left there uncompleted.All in all the game isn't necessarily a bad game, but there's nothing to make it good either. I was expecting more given all of the great reviews. I'd officially rate the game as average: okay, but nothing special. I wish Steam gave a "neutral" button when deciding how to rate the game, but "not recommended" is the better choice of the two recommended options. Cheers.

												An astoundingly poor port. Ran very poorly on my previous computer, despite it being up to spec. Vsync destroyed performance, and the screen tearing is horrendous. content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This game has its fun moments. The battle animations are cool and I always love to see games with strong art direction. Darksiders has been compared to Zelda and I would say that for the most part, that's a decent comparison. There are temples with puzzles and new weapons to collect and a big boss to fight at the end. It's a good formula.But my problem with this game is that it's gratuitous. After slogging through one too many arena-style battles featuring wave after wave of enemies... it got old. I just wanted it to end. The level of violence in this game is pretty gruesome, and going into this game, I knew it was a stretch for me. Maybe some people get a thrill out of splitting enemies in half or ripping the wings off of angels, but again, this got tiresome and trite pretty quickly.It also doesn't help that virtually every character in this game is some gravel-voiced dude whose character motivations, if they even exist, are hidden behind in-game fantasy jargon. It's been a while since I've played, but from what I remember, they have special names for all kinds of eternal creatures or gods or places, and after a while, I started forgetting who was who and why I should care. Most of the cutscenes could be summed up with "listen to this deep-voiced guy say cool words." If it wasn't that, it was "watch this super muscular guy graphically slice up some enemies."So if this what a Westernized version of Zelda looks like... I'll stick with the original, thanks.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												I felt like Darksiders did some things right but the main components of the game felt wrong. There are 2 aspects of the game which I think Vigil did right, and that is the sound (voice acting and music) and the art design. Both are well polished and interesting. War looks like a real badass and sounds like one too. But this game is a 'hack and slash' so the combat should be the main focus, and this is where I felt the game fell short. It felt clunky and slow to put it bluntly. Blocking is extremely awkwards because the put the same button to block as they did dash when you're moving in a direction. So when trying to block you more often than not dash, which can result in you getting hit. And I hate getting hit. Juggling also ties into blocking with how enemies behave. Small things like a certain grunt enemy (which are plentyful) do a ground bash that somehow also hits you in the air, which it honestly shouldn't (I mean, it is a ground attack), causing you to lose your juggle as well as being unblockable. The lock-on system and free aim systems are both awful. When locking on it changes your camera angle so you frequently can't see what is behind you and it is also awkward trying to change between targets. Free aiming is exponentially worse. It is difficult to describe in words, but the aiming is slow, clunky, awkward, and so frequently used it makes for a terrible gaming experience. What's more is that parts when you have to hit something with your projectile weapons is made that much harder because the game forces you to use the free aim controls, instead of just locking on to what you need to hit. I think this is unecessary to the overall experience of platforming. Manouvering the game world is also a chore in my opinion. Darksiders is a hack and slash, and world design in such games needs so be concise and straight forward, or in other words somewhat linear. Backtracking or having an open level design is fine, exemplified in Devil May Cry 4 for example. But Darksiders has a world designed more like and RPG than the traditional hack and slash and it is painful trying to navigate it. War moves rediculously slow, especially when you're just trying to move from A to B in a big, open space. Moving from area to area is more bearable with a quicktravel system, but that involves War walking from one portal to another in some ethereal space. It takes 2 minutes but it is rediculously tedious. There is absolutely no need for it. My verdict is that if you can pick up both Darksiders I and II for 10 bucks or less, you can do worse for your money. But small nuances in the gameplay degrade the overall experience too much, and I believe if you want a better hack and slash game you should play Devil May Cry 4 or earlier (not DMC).

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												It breaks my heart to thumb down this because I love Joe Madureira and his work on Battle Chasers.To be blunt, from artistic stand point the game is flawless, but then again art is made by MAD! so it's expected.Combat is fast paced enough but what annoys me is they basically copy - pasted some moves/upgrades such as Nero's Devil Bringer (DMC4) or shameless Portal gun copy.However the big weakness in this game lies in the fact it super saturated with puzzles, and I don't mean Soul Reaver 2 kind of puzzles, but "bring that potato over there" or "slightly move this thing to go to the other thing that you must move", unlike Soul Reaver 2 however, there is no combat mixed between the puzzle pacing to break the mood, and the puzzles are repetitive at most  and lack of the rewarding feeling is sensed. It becomes really boring and I just know that new area == more boring puzzles... I really hate that, I recommend them do one play trough of the original DMC1.Joe, this was a nice try and I hope you succeed with the upcoming Battle Chasers game.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Short and sweet: It's a good game! However --do not-- get this for PC if you can avoid it. It is TERRIBLY optimised and BARELY functions without the proper settings.Here's the only way I could get it to work for Windows 10 Professional: it WILL NOT function or run unless forced to run in windows 98 compatibility mode (Yes Windows 98! Not even XP or anything past could make it run).Here's the only way I could get it to minimize the BRUTAL stuttering issues down to moderate stuttering through the whole game after lots of research: Google "Skyrim Stutter Fix" and use the d3d9.dll and antilag.cfg to help lower the degree (but not get rid of) all the stuttering in the game.Deleting two of the start up films helps reduce load up times but --does not-- affect any of the booting issues in Windows 10 Professional.Also other known issues: DO NOT tab out of the game when it is running or it will often desync achievements with Steam if not outright crash. In order to make sure Steam achievements work then exit steam, re-open steam and open DarkSiders as the first fresh game on steam start up. Never tab out. Once done playing, fully exit steam and re-open before playign DarkSiders again.That's about all the major issues to cover if you just want to even try to play the game among possible other issues and crashing. Do yourself a favor and play this somewhere other than PC.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												I highly recommend NOT PURCHASING THIS GAME. If you want an RPG I highly reccomend you consider checking out Dark Messiah of Might and Magic instead.The game is terrible. You'll get the feeling that the designers wanted to do way more than they could handle or afford rather than adding core elements and refining it. Controls for KB/M are complete trash as it is more than blatantly obvious control scheme was never meant for anything other than a controller. Graphics are lackluster, Darksiders is 6 years old released in 2010 but looks and feels worse than some games with midrange budgets that were released pre 2006. I love RPGs and I didn't come into the game with high expectations so there was nothing to be let down on, it is just not enjoyable to play.  The sales + reviews made it out to be better than it is, honestly I'm not sure why the over reviews are "Very positive".3/10. Not even deserving of an A for effort.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												When this game game out, pc gamers finally got the third person, puzzle solving, hack and slash game we deserved all these years. dont let the possibly slow beginning push you away. give this game a good 30 minutes and you shant regret it!a very nice variety of weapon customization, brilliant puzzles that progressively increase in difficulty to ease you in on it, great battle combos, interesting voice acting and story telling, AND THE BEST ENDING IN A VIDEOGAME I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED. the ending had me daydreaming for a sequel, and we got a very deserving one!textures seem a little outdated, but not nearly enough for me to complain about it, although some people might consider this a negative.when you finish this game, and finish the second one as well, your mind will be blown in how the story is told. the two games are linked in  such a special way, that just kills me inside, thinking of the fact that we might not see a third installment in the series

												Please note that I didn't dislike what I played of this game. This isn't a negative review based on gameplay, it's based on this particular copy of the game. When I downloaded this game I was excited to play it and at first didn't realize the major problem that was going on. I didn't have any cenimatics. Not one. No intro to the story, or the characters, or the setting. I was just thrown into a tutorial battle. I played through the tutorial twice, thinking I might have just missed something, and the second time through discovered that I didn't have a story. Just a bunch of fighting. I enjoyed the fighting, it was challenging enough for me to casually enjoy it. But I don't want to play the game without the story.

The second one changes too much, and makes the series more of a dissappointment rather than a fun memory. Also, the developers no longer will be making any more games past Darksiders 2, even though 4 is really the only amount of games that would complete the series, if not more.

												This had to have been one of the most repetitive games I've ever played. There's very little variation throughout the game which makes it extremely boring.The game is the same from start to finish. Everywhere you go and every step you take, enemies spawn. number of helpful: 9 of 22 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This game confuses me. Actually... no. The game does not confuse me, but rather trying to write a review for it does. Why? Because it's extremely difficult to recommend on account of being one of the worst console ports i've ever seen. Some parts of the game are extremely difficult to do with keyboard and mouse, though not impossible. It's much better suited for a controller I'm assuming (I don't have one), and so if you have one you may be able to ignore what I just wrote here.And yet it's not entirely a bad game. Control issues aside, the game itself is competent, if somewhat unremarkable. The story is pretty forgettable, but the combat is pretty good. Especially so once you get the upgrades. However, it also has a really screwy difficulty curve: the game is at its hardest early on, with the first "real" boss (Tiamat) being the most brutal. Speaking of that bat-monster, I ran into a game-killing glitch right before fighting her that didn't open the door to her lair despite me having done everything necessary to make that happen. I had to go in and delete a file in the game folders to let me move on. The rest of the game was fairly smooth glitch-wise, but alot of the "puzzles" were more exercises in frustration more than anything else.Ultimately, i'd say get this on a console instead. It may be better there and more playable than this version. There's a decent game in here, but the PC port here screws it up. It's playable, but not good enough for me to recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Oiled by the tears of innovation, Darksiders delivers a truly fullfiling experience that will scratch every action-adventure itch you have. You'll have so much fun playing it, you won't have time to address the nagging guilt you feel.What guilt, you ask? Why, the guilt that comes from rooting on the bad guy! And in this case, the 'bad guys' are the developers of Darksiders. To suggest that Darksiders takes 'inspiration' from Prince of Persia, The Legend of Zelda and Devil May Cry is somewhat like suggesting that a spork takes 'inspiration' from a spoon and a fork. Darksiders unabashedly loots and presents ideas as their own, producing a product that could best be described as a Triple-A Fangame covered in abject plagiarism. And yet... it's really good. Like, super good. It's everything I wanted from a Frankensteinian monster. This must be what making a deal with the devil feels like.And it never felt so good.

Posted: August 29, 2016
												I think the problem is this is designed for console and plays very badly on PC.  It seems that to use any of the advanced attacks you'd need 3 hands or some other inhuman anatomy to perform the vulcan death grip needed followed by concern pianist like coordination and reflexes to change keys.  Past that, it does a poor job of explaining things leaving you confused as to why you seemingly can't use an item you were given, or how you're actually equiping things.  And then you randomly pick up a barrel and can't drop it and while holding it can't open chests or use your sword until you find something to hit with the barrel so you drop it.  Again, I'm not a console gammer, don't have a gamepad, and that could be the whole of my issue here, I just found it unplayable pretty quick.  Also, 6 clicks to exit a game including one to start?  And then it has to run an uninstaller before you can actually delete it?  All around weird and clunky and doesn't want to die.

												Starting of with the positive about this game:-Good graphics for being this old.-The combat is quite fun.-Fun with that you can move around wherever you want even after you passed certain areas.And now with the negative regarding this game:-Random game crashes (Nothing wrong with my PC, can play all the games I have on ultimate graphic settings)-Sometimes it messes up the mouse sensitivity on my mouse, making it super slow and I have to unplug it and plug it in again to regain the normal one. Never had this kind of issue with any other games.-The achievements are broken, like "Defeat [input boss name]" doesn't register, aquire that certain weapon, doesn't register and such like that. I personally HATE when they put achievements in games that are broken, which mess up the fun if you're an achievement hunter.-Quite expensive (around 20 euros), wouldn't buy it unless it was 75% off deal.I quite enjoy the game, but thanks to the negative reasons I put up there, I can't recommend the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												I wanted to like Darksiders almost as hard as Darksiders kept trying to be God of War. I tried really, really hard.The concept is cool. Book of Revelation, four horsemen of the apocalypse, yaddayadda. Like any brawler the point is simple: smash dudes. Lots of dudes. Even if I don't much care for the Warhammer 40,000/World of Warcraft proportions and pauldrons fetish that Darksiders's art direction makes ample use of, the visuals are pretty good. The voice acting is fitting, given what script the VAs had to work with. And on that note, the characterization is about as shallow as either W40K or WoW's; angry guy is angry, thus, he does angry things. I didn't expect masterful writing going in, but when even mediocrity counts as a positive bullet point in a review, it heralds bad things to come.There's only one category where Darksiders really shines, and that's the boss fights. The introductory cutscenes are great, the battle mechanics themselves are usually pretty neat, you feel great for fighting and winning, you get to watch War perform some pretty brutal finishers on the bosses at the end, and there is no annoying underwater fight to speak of. A+.The final boss is the worst, though. No, not The Destroyer. The final final boss.The protagonist, War, and the final final boss, the camera, are introduced in the same cutscene sequence when you first fire up Darksiders and select New Game. And if you know anything about the camera angles in pre-rendered cutscenes, it's that you can't actually move them. Get used to a lot of that; Darksiders is an ongoing and constant battle of atrition against atrocious perspective shots, awkward lock-on phases, and jarring transitions.When clinging to platform edges and ledges embedded in walls that you can strafeclimb across, it can be difficult to see where you're going- especially if you need to leap to something behind you and you're in an enclosed area. The camera often can't be coerced to give you a view of where you're headed in such cramped quarters, so prepare to make many a leap of faith.At times, the target lockon feature avoids traditional third-person, over-the-shoulder camera angles in favor of side-facing perspectives that skew your controls by 90 degrees and throw your depth of field off, resulting in many swing-and-a-miss and failed dodge scenarios on your part.The lockon feature lets you cycle through enemies, but not consistently. On occasion, it will only toggle back and forth between the same two enemies instead of cycling over to whichever bigger threat you're trying to look at.During battle sequences the camera will often be hijacked to show the arrival of more enemies from somewhere near the area. When control is reluctantly returned to the player, you are often not facing exactly the same direction you were when the camera was stolen from you. You are not always finished fighting when this happens, either, which only exacerbates the problem.The awful teleportation mechanic introduced in the later part of the game wreaks havoc with the camera angle, snapping it to a fixed position and holding it there for just a second too long. Even if you look through your portals to preview where you're going, your perspective will be seized from you the moment you step through them, forcing you to react the way the game wants you to instead of the way you planned. Trial-and-error is not a fun mechanic.Sensitivity is not consistent between different game views. In the handful of shooter segments, your aim is off-the-walls oversensitive. In the brawler and platformer segments, the camera is much less sensitive. I found myself switching the game's camera sensitivity back and forth to try to compensate.Entire swaths of the puzzles in Darksiders feel unnecessary. There's a lot of time-based puzzle mechanics that involve a lot of waiting to reset if you make a mistake.Toss in an uncooperative camera that won't let you look up to see when it's safe to proceed until you're already hanging from the ceiling and the time-slowing Chronospheres to make you wait that much longer when the spinning fan blade you couldn't see coming knocks you down, and you've got a recipe for half an hour wasted on multiple, identical, really badly-designed obstacles in the Ashlands.Or, worse than player-controlled timers, there are entire rooms in the Dark Throne area in the later part of the game with floors that automatically build and remove themselves in cycles. If you miss the chance to step onto the path when it appears near you, you have to wait for the cycle to circle the entire room in order to continue. At least one of these also features a player timing puzzle.Darksiders features what most gaming circles call "artificial difficulty." The harder game modes bump up the damage enemies do and, possibly, the number of enemies and the number of waves of enemies you face, but they don't become more intelligent or actually more challenging to destroy; they just take longer to finish off. My first run was on Apocalyptic, the hardest difficulty setting. When I briefly tried again on Easy to see what the differences were for this review I noticed a stark difference in survivability- mine and the enemy's- but I didn't play long enough to really see if there were fewer enemies to fight. It felt that way but I can't confirm.My biggest complaint with the artificial difficulty is that it's irritating to be one-shot by some of the bigger baddies in the early game when you don't know how to fight them. Dark Souls players might find the challenge enjoyable, but the difficulty spike feels out of place in a brawler like this one. As I played, however, I picked up more Lifestones and was able to mitigate this problem. But it's still a problem.In the beginning of the game, when I was instructed how to toggle between running and walking, I was ecstatic. My joy quickly turned to despair when I realized that the player's default state is running. War's movement speed is agonizingly slow. This could be mitigated by Ruin, the demonic steed depicted in the game's promotional matierals, but Darksiders has a huge problem: you play one of the four horsemen, but you don't get many opportunities to ride his horse.It's unfortunate because everything in the game is either far too speedy or War is much too slow, though I suspect it's a combination of both. The result is a lot of chasing enemies around or trying to wade through piles of mooks to deal with the real threats and failing because everything can strafe circles around you. Thanks to a really jarring pause at the end, your dash is useless as a way to close real distance and seems to feature variable invincibility frames on top of it. I could never figure out what I did differently when I succeeded or failed; dodging always felt like a gamble.I experienced a handful of bugs while playing Darksiders, and if you look into my screenshot gallery for the game, you'll be able to see the few I had time to snag pictures of. In my playthrough of Darksiders, I......fell through the world, twice...got stuck in level geometry and couldn't escape, several times...got stuck in the Serpent Holes because the end portal didn't appear, once...got stuck in midair after being knocked out of an aerial combo attack, once...got pushed out of bounds underwater, "died", and respawned on land with less health, oncehttp://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=776105436http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=776098965I can't speak for the original PS3 and Xbox 360 releases, but this first PC port is garbage. Maybe the remastered version is playable, but this one isn't unless you're into sadomasochism. Skip it. I'm going to complete Darksiders, because I don't want to let it sit unfinished in my Steam library... but it isn't going to be fun.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												I really wish there was a "Meh" option instead of just thumbs up and thumbs down.   Oh well.  I don't recommend it mainly for it being just a clone of God of War that was rather mediocre.   It didn't do anything wrong, really, it just didn't do anything great either.   The dungeons were boring, the bosses were pointlessly repetetive, and the combat was just dull button mashing.  Heavily padded with filler content to stretch the play time.  The story was a ridiculous butchery of a mythos with every word of dialogue just mind numbing in how desperately it tried to be over-the-top-epic.  Chock full of generic tropes.   Ytf does the (useless) magic pistol have casings coming out of it?  I did like the way they were trying to go for a bit of a Zelda thing with it, but it was so linear, the idea just failed. The Watcher is an altogether pointless and stupid character who never once says anything that isn't annoying and obvious and should've been cut from the game altogether. "Doesn't look like you can do anything against this [large gay spider], better avoid it"   ...Despite having just killed hordes of giant demons and three Demon Lords with little effort.  Riight.All in all, this game is hella mundane.  If you didn't play it when it was new, don't waste your time. Hopefully the sequel will prove more enjoyable.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Horribly repetitive, boring, bland game. The combat gets repetitive FAST. You can probably level the same complaint at most action/RPG games, but at least games like Titan Quest and Diablo give you enough loot, skill/talent upgrades and weapon upgrades to make it an intereseting journey. Darksiders does not. If you are a PC gamer, you are accustomed to better games than this. This is a PC port of a console game and it plays like it. The area graphics (anything that is not a character) are bland and boring (and look quite dated, really). Again, probably a product of it being made for consoles. Just skip it. There are better games out there.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Let me say this before: I do not recommend this game at full price, when I took it was at -90% and only for that price I would take it again or suggest it to you... maybe.I will not tell you what's Darksiders about, there are tons of older reviews and web pages, I will simply tell you why I didn't fully appreciate my experience with this game (I quit it just before the last mission and complete it months later in a moment of boredom).-Many bugs that will never be fixed such as: achievements that randomly don't work, clipping or falling from the world (I'm sure that you will experience this last one when you will fight  The Stygian  I begin to consider to throw in the sponge after that fight).-The bosses are a joke.-Sometimes the cut-scene are just used over and over again and it's not possible to skip.-Combat is fluid but never evolves/changes.-Controls for keyboard/mouse are quite bad without any way to configure them, use a controller instead.-There is nothing new in the game about mechanics or style.Ofc the game has some good points too, I had a bit of fun when I wasn't mad because one of the previous points, the characters are nice and I liked the acting voice, the story was ok and let's not forget about the blood, demonic blood and angel blood :D.So take the game when it's on sale if you like the action/hack and slash games but do not expect too much.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												I don't understand why would anyone waste his time in this "experimental" game while there are really good hack and slash games!The game has good general gameplay & story concepts and mechanics, but overall it has way many flaws to deserve such high percentage of positive ratings as 95%, this is the game that will make me officially pay ZERO attention to Steam reviews in the future, it's very deceptive if you look at all these positive reviews and think it is a masterpiece but then realized it's a medicore game at its best.Let me lest a few of the negatives:1- Worst controls I have ever seen in a video game, like really; I didn't even know what are "bad controls" until I tried this game, I am still wondering how on earth those hundreds of developers didn't see that the controls are that bad and awkward to use while nearly 99% of the players and reviewers saw that?!!2- Camera angels are very bad and often get blocked by your character's back, and if you are aiming you can't move the camera freely because the developers think the enemy you are aiming for will stand there and wait for you to throw your weapon at without moving around!3- There is no dodge button which is very silly in a "hack and slash" game, what's there is a "dash" button which is useless in crowded combat scenes since your character pauses for a little bit if you use it, meaning that you will avoid the first hit but you will definitely get hit by another enemy because you can't "re-dash" again due to this 1 second pause period!4- You can't change the difficulty, so if you stuck due to high difficulty or just want more challenge if you find the game easy you can't.5- Puzzles are repetitive and have the same concept but in different areas, at least those that I have experienced so far.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2013
												Слешер перенасыщенный головоломками, которые не столько для ума, сколько для реакции. Раз 5 за игру испытывал откровенное утомление от игры, но перебарывал себя, так как хотелось допройти. Если бы я играл снова, то ставил бы игру на easy, чтобы не париться, потому что если хочешь бежать и рубить всех подряд, то тебе не нужны головоломки, а так как головоломок избежать нельзя, то слешер превращается скорее в что-то активное между головоломками. Вы заметили что текст перенасыщен головоломками? Это потому что они оголоволомили меня.Игра нарисована с уклоном в японскую сторону. Местами привлекательна, местами утомительна. Сюжет забавный, но много где крайне наивный, но тут не в наивности цимес. Могло получиться куда лучше, но то что получилось тоже может понравиться тем, кто, скажем, любит новых принцев персии и тематику битв ангелов и демонов. Странная игра. Оставила неоднозначное впечатление. Рекомендация: брать по 75% скидке со второй частью вкупе.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												This game was highly recommended and I simply did not think it was very interesting.After we've seen so many God of War style hack and slash games and arpgs, this just feels uncomfortable. The game itself is very cartoon-ish. Graphics are bright and cheerful, even in many of the darker areas. Battles feel dull since attacks have no real weight behind them. Collectibles are boring and more of a hassle to collect than necessary. Plot line feels uninspired and empty. PS1 style world with inaccessible areas that appear to be within reach.I would recommend Dante's Inferno before this game, and God of War next. Save your money for a more intense game or one with more replay value.

number of helpful: 0 of 8 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												So I've finally gotten around to playing Darksiders this week.  It's been called Ocarina of Time mashed up with God of War.  I've never played God of War, but it certainly feels a LOT like Ocarina.  It's fun, to be sure, but it's inferior in a couple of ways.  The most glaring is that it's SUPER linear. At least the first 5 hours I've played has been. Whereas most Zelda games resemble an open world (even though the sequence of events is linear).  Darksiders very much funnels you from arena to puzzle to arena and is far easier than Ocarina.Less obvious is where the theme, plot, and characters fall far short of Zelda.  You'd think that playing as one of the Horsemen of the apocalypse, War, and battling demons, being a general badass would be freaking amazing.  It's really not.  Because of the overly grandiose nature of your character and the plot, you really can't connect with any of it on any level, and it feels like you're just going through the motions to get the game done, and it really doesn't effect you in any IRL capacity.Contrast that with Ocarina, wherein you are a mysterious little boy given the gift of this task of saving your loved ones from a mysterious malevolence starting with nothing at all and finally becoming a young adult with a kick butt arsenal and mad skillz.  A little more dynamic, emotionally, than, "Hey, you're War, you start out powerful and get more powerful.  Have fun killin' stuff."Overall the game is fun, and worth playing so long as you don't expect it to be different from anything else you may have already played.  A solid hack'n'slash with a great aesthetic.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Let me put this game into perspective for you.It is the End War. The armies of Heaven and Hell have both broken loose and seek to destroy all before them.YOUR job is to grind the nations of the Earth into dust and usher in the Apocalypse.And that's just the tutorial.DARKSIDERS II: Deathinitive EditionTHE FOLLOWING IS A PRE-PLAYED REVIEW OF DARKSIDERS II: DEATHINITIVE EDITION. I HAVE NOT SUNK A SINGLE MINUTE OF PLAYTIME INTO THIS VERSION OF THE GAMESo I've been reading the reviews for Darksiders II: Deathinitive Edition. I still hate the term Deathinitive. Let me go on the record saying that right now.Anyways, reviews are mixed for DSII:DE, and this may turn people away from actually considering getting it, because Mixed Reviews means that the game is at about 60/40 or 50/50 on good/bad reviews. But there is a very valid reason as to why this is.It is because the PC Gaming community which I happen to be part of is a bunch of self entitled little ♥♥♥♥♥. We have people whining that, because they bought DSII, but not all the DLC, they should get DSII:DE (which features a graphical upgrade AND every single DLC released for it), they should be getting the game for free, , because they are just getting a "graphical polish that should have been there in the first place" (in their eyes), as opposed to getting it at 80% off (about 6 bucks American). Let me be clear. These guys are whining because they have to pay SIX BUCKS. PS4 and Xbox One users have to pay full price for the game. These guys get 80% off of a game on release day. RELEASE DAY! How often do you hear about a game being 80% off for ANYONE on release day?Besides. Don't blame Nordic Games for this. Blame Steam for making it impossible for Nordic to reward their fans the way they wanted to anyway. They intended to give a free copy of the Deathinitive Edition to anyone who had bought Darksiders II plus the DLCs, but Steam forced their hand to have it be those who had bought the Darksiders Franchise Pack (Darksiders, Darksiders II, the soundtrack for both, a Darksiders Prequel Comic, and all the DLC for Darksiders 2 wrapped up into a single-purchase package). My previous post already went over the various Loyalty Tiers available, even having a tier for "New members of the Darksiders Franchise", read, people who haven't paid a single red cent for their games.So yes. A full two-thirds of the negative reviews are just entitled brats whining about having to pay 6 dollars for a game that costs 30. ♥♥♥♥ them.The rest of the reviews complaining about 1.) how buggy the game is, or 2.) being unable to purchase Darksiders II now. As in, the regular version, NOT the Deathinitive Edition. The second category of negative reviews can be safely discarded.Bugs in a game, especially on launch day, should be expected. Some of the bugs listed are in fact quite valid. Example: Some of the reviewers bought/unlocked/played the game on the first day. They all had the same issue. The game would get to the main menu, they would start a new game, and they would Crash to Desktop. And they wrote an angry review saying "don't buy his broken game, ♥♥♥♥ nordic games for ♥♥♥♥ing with the game"And that is a very valid review for a very valid problem. If you can't play the game, any price above free is too high to pay. Thankfully, after the bombed port that was Batman: Arkham Knight, Steam has a refund option, an option these people took. But that wasn't the end.See, those that stuck around beyond the First Day Crash bug found out something. Nordic was listening. and Nordic started fixing the various bugs players pointed out. Starting with the Crash Bug, which was fixed on day 2, which is why it is referred to as the First Day Crash Bug, because it was only experienced by people who bought the game and played it on the first day. Since then, over the past 15 days, Nordic has been responding to any bug reports they get, and dealing with them accordingly. Did you have a Season Pass to Darksiders II? Email them proof, and you will get a Steam Key to the Deathinitive Edition. Just activate it and boom, done. The game is yours now. Many of the issues the negative reviewers are complaining about (excepting the ones whining about paying 6 bucks for a thirty dollar game) HAVE BEEN DEALT WITH.REPEAT FOR THE PEOPLE IN THE BACK. NORDIC GAMES IS ACTIVELY WORKING ON FIXING ANY AND ALL ISSUES THAT GAMERS FIND WITH THEIR DEATHINITIVE EDITION OF DARKSIDERS II.THEY ARE NOT BEING WB GAMES AND LEAVING IT A MESS LIKE WB DID WITH ARKHAM KNIGHT. THEY ARE CLEANING IT UP AND MAKING SURE IT WORKS, TO MAKE SURE EVERYONE CAN ENJOY THEIR GAME. AND I CAN SAFELY SAY IT IS THEIR GAME, BECAUSE NORDIC GAMES HAS IN FACT RECRUITED THE OLD DARKSIDERS CREW FROM VIGIL GAMES (Hopefully to work on Darksiders III)One final thing to note. Apparently, according to one reviewer, a lot of people were complaining about how DSII:DE wasn't running at full 60 fps on max settings even though they had super souped up rigs. This perplexed this user because he had a modern rig, and was experiencing the same things. He found a fix for this. And it apparently is that you just need to rollback your hardware to an earlier version, and it will run like a dream (Applicable to NVidia users, cannot speak for AMD). Don't ask me how that works, I don't have a ♥♥♥♥ing clue. Also the System Requirements section on DSII:DE is now slightly archaic and innacurate.So the vast majority of the negative reviews on DSII:DE can be broken into three types of people~~People whining for paying 6 dollars for a AAA game (even though this AAA game is at about a third of the cost of a Standard AAA Game. CoD sells for about, what, sixty bucks on release? and its ♥♥♥♥ing CoD!!!)~~People griping about bugs, but didn't stick around for them to be fixed~~People who found the game running less than absolutely perfectly on frames per second, and blamed the game company, instead of their hardwareSO. WHEN YOU ARE LOOKING THROUGH THE REVIEWS OF DARKSIDERS 2, DISREGARD THOSE TYPES OF NEGATIVE REVIEWS ENTIRELY, BECAUSE THEY ARE ♥♥♥♥♥ING AND WHINING, NOT BECAUSE THE GAME IS BAD, BUT BECAUSE THEY ARE ENTITLED LITTLE ♥♥♥♥♥.Instead, do what I do when looking at buying a game. Read the reviews, yes. It's how you find out if a F2P multiplayer game is F2P/P2W (Free to play, pay to Win). Those types of games need to be weeded out and destroyed. But as for everything else, read reviews, but watch some gameplay footage on Youtube. You'll get some spoilers, sure. But you will also get a look at the style of the game. The controls, unfortunately, you won't know unless you play it. Some people like the control scheme for Brutal Legend, some people don't. That's a case by case basis that the reviews can't particularly grasp.As far as my review for Darksiders II goes, here it is.Zelda-esque puzzles, God of War's hack and slash combat, Brutal Legend's fantastical art design, and some of inFAMOUS's platforming style all get together and have a big, massive orgy pile in Diablo II's dropped loot mechanic, and Darksiders II was the baby. If you liked a majority of these things, then you will enjoy Darksiders II, I can almost assure you.So final verdict: "Is it good?" I hear you ask, to which I say "Yes!""Is it for Everyone out there?" I hear you continue, to which I respond cheekily "Is ♥♥♥♥ing anything?"If you liked Darksiders and have been considering getting Darksiders II, go ahead. If you liked Darksiders II, you'll not be getting much new, and it will be more of the same, but CoD, HALO, and Assassin's Creed gamers are getting more of the same with each subsequent release yet they don't seem to mind paying full price for it

												Love this game. The combat is fun and challenging and the story is awesome. Who doesn't want to play as one of the Horsemen of the Apocalypse? The puzzles you have to do in order to get to the bosses are challenging and need a good amount of thought to figure out. However, the bosses are kinda lackluster. Their designs are great, but they are soooooo easy. The only one that was challenging was the first one, Tiamat. Even the Destroyer was too easy. I literally stood in front of him till he took 5 lives out of my eight and beat him with 2 lives left. I was playing on normal, but from what i hear, it's basically the same story on Apocalyptic. Besides the bosses being easy, its a great game, totally recommend it. 10/10 would fall in a chasm 8947 times again

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.Gameplay: For all intents and purposes, I should absolutely love this game. Many people make the comparison between this and Legend of Zelda, and I am certainly in that camp. Why I say that I should absolutely love this game is because my biggest beef with the 3D Zelda games has been the combat. It's not bad, but it certainly could be a lot better. This game does have better combat than the 3D Zelda games. So why don't I like it as much as I should? Here's a few reasons why.One of the reasons why I'm not too keen on this game is the combat itself. Yes, it is much better than the Zelda games, but it's just too clean. I'm not talking about violence or anything; there's plenty of that. Rather, the combat just feels really light and floaty; there's no weight to it. Admittedly, games like Dark Souls may have spoiled me on weighty combat, but Darksiders just feels sterile to me; you don't feel like you're there hacking up enemies. Mechanically, the combat is very sound, but it just lacks the feel I think a hack-and-slash game should have. Boss fights are a bit of a mixed bunch; no bosses are terrible, but some of them are just kinda meh.In fact, "meh" kinda gets to the point of why I don't like this game as much as I probably should. The whole journey just feels like a "been there, done that" sort of adventure. It's not the easiest thing to describe in words, but this game just feels soulless to me. There are some inspired bits here and there, but they only account for about 20% of the game's running time. The biggest mark against this game has to be the dungeon where you get what is basically the Portal Gun. I can't help but feel that the game design meeting for this section went along the lines of, "Hey, you know what's popular? Portal. Let's do a Portal section." Again, there are a few clever uses of the Portal gadget, but it just reeks of the designers giving up.Despite these three paragraphs of negativity toward the game, I can recommend it if you're looking for a Zelda-like game that has better combat than Zelda. Just don't go into it with too high of standards. I would use the phrase "Diamonds in the rough" to describe the good bits in this game, but I feel that's a bit too harsh of a comparison. Rather, I think "Garnets in the Styrofoam Peanut Pile" is a good comparison. There's good sections and bosses in there. You just gotta wade through a lot of mediocre stuff to get to them. 6/10.Story: The story is actually mildly inspired by the Biblical story of the Apocalypse and the coming of the Horsemen. By this I mean that there is some other original stuff added to it so that it's not a complete carbon copy, much like a lot of the game is anyways. However, this game just tries way too hard in my opinion to be cool. Also, "Creator" and "Destroyer"? What's so bad about God/Jehovah/YHWH/whatever you wanna call him vs. Lucifer? I get that hiding the identity of the "Destroyer" is actually relevant to the plot, but the story is clearly inspired by the story in Revelations (New Testament stuff, so no crossover with Judaism), so why not just call the character God? I'm making petty complaints, though. It's alright, but the writer really needed to lay off with the angst, especially with some of War's dialogue. 6/10.Graphics: The art style isn't actually half bad in this game. I dug some of the enemy designs, even if they were repeated quite a bit with "color palette switcheroo"-esque changes. Plus, many of the areas have a very "big" feeling to them, a feeling that I love seeing in areas in video games. Some people say that War's character design could've been a lot better, and while I agree, I don't think it's that abysmal. After all, Square Enix has had MUCH worse character designs than War. Now, on the technical side of things, there unfortunately isn't very much in the way of graphical fidelity control. There's no option for Anti-Aliasing or Anisotropic Filtering, which is quite disappointing for a game released in 2010. There's also no option for windowed mode, so if you're a person who likes playing game in windowed mode, you're kinda stuck. Fortunately, the game does run at 1080p, which it does run fairly well and fairly cool on my GTX 760 with all the settings that I could max out maxed out. However, I again suspect that the reason why it does run cool is because they never implemented the high-end features. 3/5.Music: The game does come with the OST, but like many orchestral soundtracks, none of the songs really left an impression on me. It's not like Dark Souls (and this is the last comparison I'll make to Dark Souls for this review; I swear) where each track is anthemic to some area. It basically comes down to a multipurpose battle theme and a multipurpose boss theme. The final bosses' theme wasn't bad, but I'd be hard pressed to remember it if you played it back to me without telling me what it was from. The voiceacting, much like the story, is very try-hard to be cool. You can hear the angst dripping off of War's lines, and it's actually kinda funny listening to the game try to be hard. Again, this may be because the VAs didn't have much to really work with, but the voiceacting is forgettable at best and absolute ham at worst. 2/5.Overall score of 6/6/3/2; 5.7/10. To refrain what I said in the intro, a 5 isn't awful in my perspective; it's just average, and that's what this game feels like to me: average. Your mileage may vary; in fact, one of my friends thought this game was worthy of a five star rating. To me, though, it's just a slightly above average hack and slash game. I wish I could give a neutral, but since my score errs on the side of a thumbs up, I guess I'll give it a very low-held thumbs up.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Legend of Zelda meets the Apocalypse. I absolutely loved Darksiders, moreso than Darksiders II. The hack n' slash was enjoyable, and while some bosses were pretty easy to beat, a couple required a fair bit of ingenuity and tenacity. The plot is absolutely amazing, and the enemies are well-designed, artistically speaking. The game does play on a few old tropes, but as an older game, I find it pretty alright. There is a little bit of grind if you decide to fully upgrade your weaponry or purchase everything, but it isn't necessary at all to enjoy the game. On Windows 7, there is also a pretty bad issue with the game randomly deciding to quit, but there are ways around that. I believe I had to launch the game offline from steam when I was running Windows 7. I've had no problems so far with 8.With the franchise looking bright once again, I'd recommend giving the game a shot!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Amazing, amazing game.  Played a few years ago on the Xbox 360 and didn't really appreciate fully what an amazing game this is.  Action, adventure, excitement.  Big freaking swords...  It has what most 30 something year old males appreciate.  Scratch that.  This is a game that every man who has ever spent at least a minute dreaming about angels, demons and kicking♥♥♥♥♥should experience.  Why?  Well, did I mention it has big swords? (see, something for women too!)As for other reasons, well, it has a wealth of interactivity, amazing (and I mean AMAZING) environments and a whole host of ungodly (and very godly!) creatures to talk to, stalk and annoy.  Want a better sword?  Talk to the dodgy demon in the park, want some currency?  Go get a few souls by killing zombies in the park.  Want a better game?  Try playing this one first before you play Darksiders 2.Haha, but no seriously, I fully intend to molest this game before I move onto the sequel, because hey, when you're onto a good thing, keep playing it.  The only downside is that like most games, there will be frustrating moments in it occasionally, be it the odd insta-death from a hard enemy or just a puzzle, but it keeps the game fresh and constantly interesting.  Also, love it of hate it, aspects of old platform games do pop up now and then and the older gamers may recognise (and chortle at) some of the random occasional nods to other forms of entertainment here and there, but from my personal experience with the game, it never detracts from the gameplay or screams in your face like some of the newer titles around.Overall, recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												I originally purchased Darksiders because I watched a good portion of a let's play series on it and it seemed like a lot of fun! I had heard negative comments here and there about the quality of the port from consoles, but I figured it couldn't be too bad, right? Well, I'll get to that...First and foremost, let's talk about the story...It's great! Really awesome premise and it's implemented very well.  Basically, you play the part of one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, War. In this game, the Horsemen exist to maintain the balance between Earth, Heaven, and Hell. Anyone who goes against this balance is quickly and brutally punished. War wakes from a long slumber by a summons to Earth because the balance has been broken. As it turns out, he (you) has been summoned prematurely, and gets in trouble for being the cause of this supposed imbalance. This starts a rather convoluted, yet very compelling, string of events in which War tries to reprove his innocence by finding the one who, essentially, framed him. Try not to stress about spoilers or anything...this is all made clear in the tutorial portion of the game :PThe other thing I'd like to point out is a personal fixation of mine - the soundtrack. As I've said before, the music in a game can be a huge factor in how well it plays, and Darksiders is no different. The music is actually very good! It's definitely a score that I would (and currently do) keep in my music collection! The downside here is that it can get very repetitive during long hours of gameplay. The whole soundtrack is outstanding, but there isn't enough diversity within the actual game to break up the monotony of listening to the same track over and over again while traversing a large distance. This actually brings me to my next point...The game is, more or less, and open world. There are only certain areas you can explore to begin with, but once you unlock an area, you can almost always return there at-will. The exceptions to this being anything related to the storyline - say if♥♥♥♥♥♥goes downhill at a place you already visited and it progresses the story to travel back there. While this by itself is a good thing, the sheer size of the world is a little off-putting. The game seems to falsely enhance its own play time by making you hold the "W" key for 5-10 minutes at a time in order to reach your destination. On top of that, there are enough random encounters to make you rip your own hair out. Setting the difficulty easier doesn't help this, either. It just makes these encounters more of a nuisance than anything else. If you have the difficulty up, then expect to die repeatedly to these unending hordes or demons while trying to get to the store.If the combat in the game was well-implemented, then all these encounters wouldn't be so bad. Unfortunately, Darksiders is no God of War. The combat style is very God of War-esque, but it, like much of the game, is also monotonous. Technically, it is very dynamic, but it's dynamic for all the wrong reasons.  There are a finite number of moves/combos that War can perform, but the odds of you even finishing a combo are pretty slim. There is a dodge mechanic that NEEDS to be used frequently if you fancy staying alive. Each combo is between 3 and 5 moves, but the fighting in practice is HIT-HIT-DODGE-HIT-HIT-DODGE-HIT-HIT-KILLING BLOW-DODGE-DODGE. There are also a very small number of finishing moves that can be performed on enemies. In the beginning, it looks like each kind of demon has a special killing blow made just for it, and that realization is terribly exciting! The excitement dies about 3 or 4 hours in, though, when you notice that the same 5 or 6 killing moves are reused for some enemies.It's right around this time that you also notice the enemies that share killing blows also share a lot of the same characteristics as well. They're not just similar...they're the SAME! Quite literally, Darksiders will use the same attack patterns, behaviors, etc. for three or even four different enemies...the only thing that changes between them are the actual models. And, even then, it's hard to see them differently when they're jumping all over your face just like the little bugs in the tutorial. WAIT! That guy jumps more frequently than the previous iteration did!>.>Lastly, the controls were obviously meant for consoles. That much becomes obvious early on in the game. Granted, the keys are all fully rebindable. But, in no computer game ever should you have to hold a button and press another in order to access an ability. Yes, you can rebind the button you need to hold, but you still need to hold the damn thing down. With mobility being almost key in this game, you pretty much have to bite the bullet and take a hit or two if you want to perform a special ability or even down a health potion. In the game's defense, you could probably spend the time and rebind all the keys such that you play only with the keyboard, but even that would present a challenge when trying to move and do just about anything else simultaneously.So, this concludes my rant about Darksiders. It is a game that I REALLY wanted to like...truly, I did! Sadly, it's hard to like something when there are such glaring problems. To be honest, I would say this game is still worth playing for the story. That is, if it was even playable on the computer. If you have an Xbox-style gamepad (cause good luck using a Playstation one), and you can bear the long hours and monotonous play. then go for it! If not, I'd recommend Youtube-ing this one. There are a number of full playthroughs that will give you the full story experience without having to deal with bad controls....the ability to skip through long journeys is a plus, too. - Mr. Talidar

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Have you played a hack n' slash before? Then you've played Darksiders. Sure it has special stuff to make it more... unique, I guess, but it still feels like the same thing I've played before.This game could have been cool, it could have been what the second managed to accomplish but it wasn't. There is literally nothing that this game offers that the second one doesn't surpass. Let me give a brief discription of what you'll encounter in this game:The main character is a whiney, pseudo-badass who has more armor than he does personality. He hates angels, apparently because they're mean to him and nothing else. I'm not surprised, I'd be mean to someone who was that big of a poser, too. The swordplay sucks. There are a very limited amount of moves you can successfully do - unlike the sequel which offers so much more in terms of combat that it's unfair to compare the two. If anything, this almost feels like a beta for that game.Enemies are boring as boring can be. Demons and angels are the only enemies and most are merely copy+pasted from the beginning of the game towards the end. I know what you're thinking, "but aren't all games like that?" No, most games offer something inbetween, even if its temporary. It gives the player a breather from the same old stuff they've already seen. This just pushes out the same enemies, aside from bosses, the whole entire game.The soundtrack reminds me of an orchestrated mess. Probably because that's exactly what it is. THERE ARE NO OPTIONS TO CHANGE THE VIDEO SETTINGS. YOU ARE STUCK WITH WHAT THEY PORTED OVER.Fun? This game delievers bits and pieces of it, but it's more a "McDonald's" experience for the most part.Skip this game, read an abriged version of the story (trust me, there's nothing there) or watch a "let's play". But whatever you do, do not spend your money on this game.Graphics 2/10Playability 7/10Gameplay 5/10Soundtrack 4/10Replayability 1/10Overall Score 4/10

content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												This is one of the coolest games I've ever played. Many people would call this a Zelda clone. Sure, you've got Zelda-inspired dungeons and exploration, but you also have a combat system similar to God of War and other action games. You can also level up weapons to unlock new skills and combos. I know what you're thinking. All of this has been done before, right? But not all of it has been put together into one amazing game. The designers managed to pull tons of styles together into one game and execute it flawlessly. Not to mention, the story is badass. Oh, and War's version of Navi? A floating spirit voiced by Mark Hamill. In his Joker voice. Seriously, this game kicks♥♥♥♥♥ Go play it now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2013
												Darksiders is an extremely fun spectacle fighter with a great art style and setting, alongside an interesting story and fantastic soundtrack. The game offers action, platforming, and puzzle gameplay with a mixture of spectacle fighting, zelda-esque drip feeds of tools and hidden goodies, and the occasional platforming section. The boss battles are rather easy once you find their weaknesses but all the bosses are varied and make for an enjoyable fight. In keeping with the Zelda/Metroid mechanic there's lots of interesting equipment to unlock, meaning you can return to areas you've previously visited and find passages/rooms which you couldn't access before, which is always fun. Most of the puzzles are quite simple up until the very end where they start to get a bit tricky. Darksiders is a great mixture of a spectacle fighter and an RPG with good mechanics, great combat, and a fun and interesting storyline!9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												I originally purchased Darksiders because I watched a good portion of a let's play series on it and it seemed like a lot of fun! I had heard negative comments here and there about the quality of the port from consoles, but I figured it couldn't be too bad, right? Well, I'll get to that...First and foremost, let's talk about the story...It's great! Really awesome premise and it's implemented very well.  Basically, you play the part of one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, War. In this game, the Horsemen exist to maintain the balance between Earth, Heaven, and Hell. Anyone who goes against this balance is quickly and brutally punished. War wakes from a long slumber by a summons to Earth because the balance has been broken. As it turns out, he (you) has been summoned prematurely, and gets in trouble for being the cause of this supposed imbalance. This starts a rather convoluted, yet very compelling, string of events in which War tries to reprove his innocence by finding the one who, essentially, framed him. Try not to stress about spoilers or anything...this is all made clear in the tutorial portion of the game :PThe other thing I'd like to point out is a personal fixation of mine - the soundtrack. As I've said before, the music in a game can be a huge factor in how well it plays, and Darksiders is no different. The music is actually very good! It's definitely a score that I would (and currently do) keep in my music collection! The downside here is that it can get very repetitive during long hours of gameplay. The whole soundtrack is outstanding, but there isn't enough diversity within the actual game to break up the monotony of listening to the same track over and over again while traversing a large distance. This actually brings me to my next point...The game is, more or less, and open world. There are only certain areas you can explore to begin with, but once you unlock an area, you can almost always return there at-will. The exceptions to this being anything related to the storyline - say if♥♥♥♥♥♥goes downhill at a place you already visited and it progresses the story to travel back there. While this by itself is a good thing, the sheer size of the world is a little off-putting. The game seems to falsely enhance its own play time by making you hold the "W" key for 5-10 minutes at a time in order to reach your destination. On top of that, there are enough random encounters to make you rip your own hair out. Setting the difficulty easier doesn't help this, either. It just makes these encounters more of a nuisance than anything else. If you have the difficulty up, then expect to die repeatedly to these unending hordes or demons while trying to get to the store.If the combat in the game was well-implemented, then all these encounters wouldn't be so bad. Unfortunately, Darksiders is no God of War. The combat style is very God of War-esque, but it, like much of the game, is also monotonous. Technically, it is very dynamic, but it's dynamic for all the wrong reasons.  There are a finite number of moves/combos that War can perform, but the odds of you even finishing a combo are pretty slim. There is a dodge mechanic that NEEDS to be used frequently if you fancy staying alive. Each combo is between 3 and 5 moves, but the fighting in practice is HIT-HIT-DODGE-HIT-HIT-DODGE-HIT-HIT-KILLING BLOW-DODGE-DODGE. There are also a very small number of finishing moves that can be performed on enemies. In the beginning, it looks like each kind of demon has a special killing blow made just for it, and that realization is terribly exciting! The excitement dies about 3 or 4 hours in, though, when you notice that the same 5 or 6 killing moves are reused for some enemies.It's right around this time that you also notice the enemies that share killing blows also share a lot of the same characteristics as well. They're not just similar...they're the SAME! Quite literally, Darksiders will use the same attack patterns, behaviors, etc. for three or even four different enemies...the only thing that changes between them are the actual models. And, even then, it's hard to see them differently when they're jumping all over your face just like the little bugs in the tutorial. WAIT! That guy jumps more frequently than the previous iteration did!>.>Lastly, the controls were obviously meant for consoles. That much becomes obvious early on in the game. Granted, the keys are all fully rebindable. But, in no computer game ever should you have to hold a button and press another in order to access an ability. Yes, you can rebind the button you need to hold, but you still need to hold the damn thing down. With mobility being almost key in this game, you pretty much have to bite the bullet and take a hit or two if you want to perform a special ability or even down a health potion. In the game's defense, you could probably spend the time and rebind all the keys such that you play only with the keyboard, but even that would present a challenge when trying to move and do just about anything else simultaneously.So, this concludes my rant about Darksiders. It is a game that I REALLY wanted to like...truly, I did! Sadly, it's hard to like something when there are such glaring problems. To be honest, I would say this game is still worth playing for the story. That is, if it was even playable on the computer. If you have an Xbox-style gamepad (cause good luck using a Playstation one), and you can bear the long hours and monotonous play. then go for it! If not, I'd recommend Youtube-ing this one. There are a number of full playthroughs that will give you the full story experience without having to deal with bad controls....the ability to skip through long journeys is a plus, too. - Mr. Talidar

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Have you played a hack n' slash before? Then you've played Darksiders. Sure it has special stuff to make it more... unique, I guess, but it still feels like the same thing I've played before.This game could have been cool, it could have been what the second managed to accomplish but it wasn't. There is literally nothing that this game offers that the second one doesn't surpass. Let me give a brief discription of what you'll encounter in this game:The main character is a whiney, pseudo-badass who has more armor than he does personality. He hates angels, apparently because they're mean to him and nothing else. I'm not surprised, I'd be mean to someone who was that big of a poser, too. The swordplay sucks. There are a very limited amount of moves you can successfully do - unlike the sequel which offers so much more in terms of combat that it's unfair to compare the two. If anything, this almost feels like a beta for that game.Enemies are boring as boring can be. Demons and angels are the only enemies and most are merely copy+pasted from the beginning of the game towards the end. I know what you're thinking, "but aren't all games like that?" No, most games offer something inbetween, even if its temporary. It gives the player a breather from the same old stuff they've already seen. This just pushes out the same enemies, aside from bosses, the whole entire game.The soundtrack reminds me of an orchestrated mess. Probably because that's exactly what it is. THERE ARE NO OPTIONS TO CHANGE THE VIDEO SETTINGS. YOU ARE STUCK WITH WHAT THEY PORTED OVER.Fun? This game delievers bits and pieces of it, but it's more a "McDonald's" experience for the most part.Skip this game, read an abriged version of the story (trust me, there's nothing there) or watch a "let's play". But whatever you do, do not spend your money on this game.Graphics 2/10Playability 7/10Gameplay 5/10Soundtrack 4/10Replayability 1/10Overall Score 4/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Amazing, amazing game.  Played a few years ago on the Xbox 360 and didn't really appreciate fully what an amazing game this is.  Action, adventure, excitement.  Big freaking swords...  It has what most 30 something year old males appreciate.  Scratch that.  This is a game that every man who has ever spent at least a minute dreaming about angels, demons and kicking♥♥♥♥♥should experience.  Why?  Well, did I mention it has big swords? (see, something for women too!)As for other reasons, well, it has a wealth of interactivity, amazing (and I mean AMAZING) environments and a whole host of ungodly (and very godly!) creatures to talk to, stalk and annoy.  Want a better sword?  Talk to the dodgy demon in the park, want some currency?  Go get a few souls by killing zombies in the park.  Want a better game?  Try playing this one first before you play Darksiders 2.Haha, but no seriously, I fully intend to molest this game before I move onto the sequel, because hey, when you're onto a good thing, keep playing it.  The only downside is that like most games, there will be frustrating moments in it occasionally, be it the odd insta-death from a hard enemy or just a puzzle, but it keeps the game fresh and constantly interesting.  Also, love it of hate it, aspects of old platform games do pop up now and then and the older gamers may recognise (and chortle at) some of the random occasional nods to other forms of entertainment here and there, but from my personal experience with the game, it never detracts from the gameplay or screams in your face like some of the newer titles around.Overall, recommend.
