number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Ok, this is a hack and slash/platform/puzzle game. It doesn't try to be everything to everyone, and it's not a clone of any other game.What I love most about this game is the art direction. I absolutely LOVE the imagery in this game! I keep coming back to it every six months or so to play through it again and am still astounded by the small details in every environment. Skulls on the walls, some with fire in their eyes, designs on the floors and ceilings, the enemies are just amazing looking, and it's just challenging enough to keep you interested. My only real gripe is the camera in this game, but I have a problem with that in every hack and slash type game. I have been in awe of the design of this game since I first picked it up; too bad it was completely lost in the sequel, which I haven't finished because it's just too boring. I mean, what other game do you get to ride a horse with flaming hooves?? Sure this game shares some mechanics with God of War, and the original Devil May Cry's, but I don't see the problem... because those games were phenomenal. Underappreciated? Yeah, this game was very, very underappreciated.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												It's The Legend of Zelda, but darker and grittier. If you thought changing into a wolf was intense, try a flame engulfed demon. The story is tight and the mythos is interesting. You get a variety of weapons and items to choose from, each with their unique purpose and advantages in battle. The developers threw in a bit of RPG elements with a leveling system for skills which didn't add too much to be honest.The game is a little short and some of it is predictable as far as action games go. It definitely doesn't have the depth that other action games (Elder Scrolls, Witchers, and even LoZs) but still, for those who are a fan of action games like LoZ, this game is worth playing.I would recommend playing the game with a controller as it seems like a much more precise experience. The game has some camera issues which the controller alleviates by giving you more control over the camera angles.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Satisfying action/puzzler that manages to land somewhere between Legend of Zelda and God of War. I felt kinda like I was playing a Zelda or Metroid (or Castlevania) game but in a gorier, darker setting.The puzzles and fights are generally challenging but not excessively so. The plot is fairly well-written and satisfying, but can sometimes be a little confusing, and the exposition is unevenly distributed. The RPG elements are satisfying, but don't allow very much customization.The graphics are getting a little dated, but still fairly pretty. The game itself is slightly unstable; it crashed 3-4 times total on my playthrough. The interface works pretty well for the most part, but I would recommend using a controller, and there are a few poor design decisions -- e.g. the "continue" option always loads the most recent auto-save, even if there's a more recent manual save.

												A mixture of FPS and RPG, in a violent and mythological twist of our modern world. The rise in power is just right, there's a large variety of powers/moves/weapons to find and use, very neat "a-la-Portal" tricks, and just tons of fun to have.One of those games I didn't expect to like, and had actually much fun with.Probably bought following a sale on Steam, I just "what-the-heck-le'ts-play-it"-ished...and enjoyed it from the beginning to the end. Best proof of that is that I actually took the time to go for all the achievements.The game actually made me buy Batman Arkham Asylum. May not seem the same at first, but they share a lot in their mixture of FPS and RPG.Definitively a must-have, and I'm eagerly waiting its sequel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2013
												 A third person hack and slash game with puzzle elements ( even a portal gun! ) allows the player to be War, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse.  War travels to earth where the forces of good and evil are waging in battle caused by a minion from hell called the Destroyer.  When War shows up both sides are confused as to why he's there because the horsemen can only be called when the seventh seal is broken...which is wasnt. A story of revenge and choas follows.  With upgradable weapons and a semi big list of different moves allows you to be all powerful against the minions of heaven and hell sent to stop you on your quest.  Secret chests scattered through every level containing health, wrath ( which allows you to do special moves ) and armor upgrades give the game a certain degree of replay after some items like the grapple are unlocked.  If you like chaining combos, button mashing, searching for secrets, and enjoy killing big bosses then try this out. Oh yeah and you can ride a horse.

												Spiritually is similar to God of War - it's a fun puzzle, adventure, fighting game. Worth playing through at least once. The story plays on Christian instead of Greek/Roman themes where you play as one of the four horseman of the apocalapyse, who strive to preserve a balance between Heaven and Hell. Think Constantine. I'm a sucker for these types of games and while this one certainly has some of the tropes of the genre (too much unnecessary button mashing for example, although much of this is removed in 2) I still had a fun time. Puzzles can take some time to figure out which is nice for a change.

												Ok, this is a hack and slash/platform/puzzle game. It doesn't try to be everything to everyone, and it's not a clone of any other game.What I love most about this game is the art direction. I absolutely LOVE the imagery in this game! I keep coming back to it every six months or so to play through it again and am still astounded by the small details in every environment. I have been in awe of the design of this game since I first picked it up; too bad it was completely lost in the sequel, which I haven't finished because it's just too boring. I mean, what other game do you get to ride a horse with flaming hooves?? Sure this game shares some mechanics with God of War, and the original Devil May Cry's, but I don't see the problem... because those games were phenomenal. Underappreciated? Yeah, this game was very, very underappreciated.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												This half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥PC port of Darksiders comes with no adjustable graphics settings except resolution, and I had to find a third-party game to stop the mouse cursor popping up in the centre of the screen every 20 seconds. In addition, some achievements failed to register, a common problem according to the forums.The game itself is a combination of God of War and Zelda, but sadly very far from being as good as either of them. The poorly thought out, illogical storyline, fanfic-grade script and entirely uncompelling characters manage to make even war between heaven and hell boring. The character models are fairly uninspired for the most part, although the environments are generally better, particularly in the first half of the game.To begin with the game is rescued by decent action gameplay, some well-designed dungeons and fun bosses. There's not a single shred of originality to be seen anywhere, but it works well enough that it's decent fun all the same. Unfortunately the last quarter of the game does its best to ruin all that, with the final dungeon stealing shamelessly from Portal - yes, you are given a portal gun for no apparent reason - and still managing to be a tedious slog with pointlessly long elevators, the same rooms and corridors repeated, and a boss that's far easier than any that have come before. Then you are given a fetch quest to go all over the map to pad out the game a little more before a final boss bereft of any real challenge or tension and a pathetic little sequel-bait ending.Don't bother.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2013
												 A third person hack and slash game with puzzle elements ( even a portal gun! ) allows the player to be War, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse.  War travels to earth where the forces of good and evil are waging in battle caused by a minion from hell called the Destroyer.  When War shows up both sides are confused as to why he's there because the horsemen can only be called when the seventh seal is broken...which is wasnt. A story of revenge and choas follows.  With upgradable weapons and a semi big list of different moves allows you to be all powerful against the minions of heaven and hell sent to stop you on your quest.  Secret chests scattered through every level containing health, wrath ( which allows you to do special moves ) and armor upgrades give the game a certain degree of replay after some items like the grapple are unlocked.  If you like chaining combos, button mashing, searching for secrets, and enjoy killing big bosses then try this out. Oh yeah and you can ride a horse.

												Now I played this game quite a while back so some of my experience is lost with time. That being said I have nothing but good memories of this game.Pros: Challenging bosses, who are huge in scale and destructive power, fairly large open ended world where there is a semblance of discovery, a interesting story line, gameplay was smooth and satisfying. Cons: Sometimes the boss's can be very challenging and dont give you very obvious finisher intel, which can be kind of frustrating after going through the motions of weakening them to that point over and over. You need to shoot for their recommended as a minimum to avoid lagging and stuttering which is not good in a game like this. Overall: 8.5/10 because it gave me a solid 30 hours of gameplay because I am a noob for the most part and took my time. Most others will finish this game in 20+, which if you ask me is still very acceptable since I got this on sale for like 10$ or something.

Posted: October 31, 2012
												An apocalypse happens but it's some Umgah-style practical joke as 7th seal wasn't broken and you, horseman War, joined the fray to punish the wicked slightly too soon, bosses strip you of powers, and you need to do some cleaning. Picking up yer old (or new) powers and toys as you go.3rd person view action adventure game.. In fighting part, it reminds me of Devil May Cry (3/4), but DMC is clearly superior there. Better story/characters and various combos that actually feel like they matter, unlike in Darksiders.Difficulty curve is bit weird, mooks way too easy, minibosses and bosses - you just have to figure out what to do, while elite mooks will give you most trouble at first. Then as your strength goes up, it's all sorta easy even on apocalyptic.But, surprise surprise, puzzling part is huge in Darksiders, you actually spend more time messing around, exploring, on scavenger hunts, rather than fighting. And I did enjoy this part very much even if it's sorta borrowing ideas around.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18, 2013
												Vigil Games' first installment in the Darksiders franchise. You play as War, a horseman of the apocalypse. Gameplay is technically like Zelda: You travel, fight and find items in order to progress throughout the story. While some will look at the gameplay and shout "God of War," the game's highest point is not about the combat; it is about the exploration and the experience of traveling in a post apocalyptic earth while meeting some characters with great acting (Especially Mark Hamill).  One of the highest appeals in my opinion is the art style that is used, very reminiscing to old 90's comic books. A normal playthrough will be about 8-9 hours at best. Collecting every item and powerup will include about 6 more (Achievements are even longer). I recommend getting it in a sale or right this instant if you don't mind paying the $20 fee. Overall a great enjoyment that Zelda and Action RPG fans will enjoy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 14, 2012
												I like to call this game Zelda for adults.  The developers basically carbon copied the structure of Zelda games, added third person hack-and-slash combat (similar to God of War I'd say) and wrapped it around the world of the Darksiders comics.  It has a pretty familiar dungeon system with locked doors and backtracking when you get the higher level gadgets (also mostly carbon copied from Zelda.)The environment is quite bland, the voice acting is mediocre, and the game has one of the worst opening sequences I've ever seen in a game; but if you give it a chance it does turn into quite a good game.  Combat is very fun and there's a lot of unlockable combos and abilities you can use to add variety.  The bosses are well-designed and fun to fight and the game rewards skill quite well.Now the PC version has a few issues and is quite a lazy port.  The game has a serious lack of video options (though it doesn't really need any honestly.)  It also uses fixed-rate mouse polling which causes the mouse speed to increase when your framerate drops which can be quite annoying.  There's also a bug which completely breaks the aimed throwing function if you change the control for throw.  But despite these problems, it still works better on PC than Darksiders 2 where they actually did try (belatedly, but they tried.)Definitely a fun game for those who would like a more adult-oriented Zelda game and for those who just like third-person hack and slash action.

												This is a surprisingly good metroidvania style game that more people need to give a chance to.It has loads of gameplay content and variety, some great level and puzzle design, amazing cartoony visuals that succeeds at  making the over the top post-apocalyptic/fantasy setting both bleak and colourful, top notch voice acting and character design (except War, which just looks silly).Yes, it steals loads of ideas from other games, but the end result is larger than the sum of its parts and a truly fun experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												How to sum up this game... part Zelda, part Devil May Cry, part God of War.The first part is Zelda because the game focuses greatly on puzzles at times. Unfortunately, the puzzles can often come off as exhausting and tedious. They're alright.The Devil May Cry part deals a lot with the Chaos Form that you get to beat the crap out of baddies with and the sword play, which is also reminicient of God of War. Probably more so God of War, but the way you can just press the B button (360 controller) to wreck enemies is just too similar to Devil May Cry 4.The game has a decent amount of collectables, but they're nothing special and might not keep you compelled to collect them all because of how bloody difficult some of them can be to find without simply looking up a guide.Lastly, this game kind of suffers from the perpetuated idea that the end of the world has mainly dull colors. Pretty much all dull colors. It doesn't keep the environments terribly fascinating and kind of wears you down after a while. The story isn't the greatest either. It's got the classic "Angels are in this game, so they have to be enemies." Seiously, how many games are there where angels aren't your enemies? I digress.This game has some fun combat and good puzzles, but it also has tedious combat and tedious puzzles. It's not the worst action/adventure I've ever played by a long shot, but it's definitely not the best. 7/10. Worth checking out if it's on a Humble Bundle or if it's on significant sale.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Great modern classic, i had never paid attention to darksiders before because im not the biggest fan of Madureira's artstyle, i mean, its cool, its quite barroque, but i dont know its not really what i prefer, but i decided to give it a try mainly because i found out that the game has a "metroidvania" feeling to it, and even though it's not a huge game nor a very complex one, it is indeed VERY solid and entertaining, the story is not bad either and Mad's style kinda grows on you, Darksiders borrows from classic action rpgs but also adds flamboyant combat techniques from more modern games, and personally i love revisiting all areas with the help of new tools and capabilities to discover secrets and optional upgrades once you are near the end, its a nice break from the story and the "duty" to do some freeroaming with the reward of getting stronger for the next boss. In few words this game is perfect, im not saying its the perfect action rpg/metroidvania/platformer or whatever u want to call it, im saying that it is in its own right perfect, the combat is fun, the puzzles are fun, and it has a great rythm.

												The story is amazingly well done. The gameplay is in your face fun. The button mashing can get a little repetitive but can be fun if you know how to do alot of the moves. The frustrating thing that was a huge upset for me was that the Steam achievements wouldn't unlock when they should. You had to restart steam and start the game right away for the achievements to work properly. Aside from that maddening bug in the game the cinematic's in game were full of detail and really fun to watch. All the enemies in the game had their own way of attacking and style as to how they approached you. The game concentrates on the "fun factor" of playing. I have really enjoyed this game and I know you will too if you like an adventure game that will make you want to come back later for more.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2012
												Wow, I mean WOW! This game blew my mind! I know there is a lot of copyright issues with it since it's sort of like a God of War/Zelda/Portal Game. But I must say that I have to give this game a 9/10. The only reason it doesn't get a 10 is for it's originality, but that is also it's greatest strength because it captures other game elements that we love and puts it in here. Also, the boss/difficulty curve is difficult at the beggining and then gets, as ZeroPunctuation puts it ♥♥♥♥♥♥easy'. Just to be clear, there is a lot of cannon fodder in this game and you will get bored if you don't get prepared for it. I recommend a God of War game before hand to get a better picture of what your in for. Overall, good game, good characters, and even some funny humor that made me ROFL. If you get a chance to buy this game on sale, I would highly recomend it. It was a good $10 spent for 20 hours of my life. I cannot wait for the sequal with the other riders.

												Darksiders is a lot like that movie Swordfish. It's completely unoriginal and steals from many different sources, but is still good. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												Darksiders is a third person action game developed by no other than sir Joe Madureira, the famous comic artist that is best known for his work with Marvel comics, and his Vigil Games studios. Despite the game being a clone of a lot of stuff, from the main character that looks just like Arthas from the Warcraft franchise, to the game mechanics that are a mixture of God of War, Devil May Cry and the like, and a lot of little things like Portal's portal gun, the great amount of work that the developers put into delivering a cinematic, engaging and varied gaming experience ultimately pays off and results in an unexpected amount of hours of fun. There really is a lot to do aside from slashing down demons(and angels) as one of the Horsemen that have the task of establishing an order between the dark and the celestial forces in Darksiders, especially solving the (rather simple but very frequent)puzzles that each section is filled with, to exploring the areas to find hidden enhancements and crates. Even the slashing down part doesnt let itself get too boring, with quite a few choices for the development of the character's abilities and moves for each weapon, the toughness of some battles and the old-style boss encounters. The puzzles, anyway, at times get just tiring and are never really challenging if you're coming from the 90s or are have at least a bunch of synapses to tie up your neurons, and the backtracking for the last hidden enhancements can get frustrating, but overall, as someone that never had too much fun with Devil May Cry, Darksiders is a very pleasant surprise even if, like me, action games are not really your cup of tea. Especially for the ridiculous price that it costs nowadays.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												God of War + Zelda + slower combat. While Darksiders is a fairly solid game, it adds nothing new to the genre -- most items are variants of quintessential Zelda items, and those that aren't have their mechanics taken from other games. The story takes a while to unfold -- the first 4 dungeons (roughly half the game) might as well be filler, honestly. But once the story gets going it really takes off. Don't let my negativity fool you, though. Overall, Darksiders is a fun game to play. Aside from achievements randomly not unlocking, which you can find plenty of complaints about online, the combat is decent and the storyline is good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2012
												Take Zelda.  Make the story more focused and voice acted, but make the world less open.  Keep the focus on puzzle based environments but increase the depth and amount of combat.  Now, take Zelda's Hyrule and replace it with a post-apocalyptic earth ruled by demons and you've got Darksiders.  It's a lot of fun and the RPGish leveling up and enchanting of your weapons gives it an added dimension.  The story, while not the best out there was still entertaining and kept moving at a pretty good pace through the campaign.  The giant boss fights were a real treat and very well made.  They all have certain puzzle elements reminicient of Shadow of the Colossus (though not nearly to that scale) that made them very stisfying to beat.  All in all a very fun game and well worth the play through.

Posted: December 5, 2011
												A Fantastic underrated gem. Darksiders features War, one of the riders of the apocalypse as the main hero venturing through a forsaken earth littered with demons standing between him and his reprieve for his sins. It combines platformer, melee/swordplay hack and slash with some RPG elements, think Legend of Zelda, God of War and Devil May Cry. (But simpler combos), It features a grim yet refreshing and somewhat cartoony setting. (gorgeous art style) There are constant upgrades and new abilities to add to your repertoire.Darksiders hits the nail right on the head. Well worth the current price tag.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												Story: 6/10Interesting new take on something that's been done before. While the eding is epic, a lot of the game seems like going from fetch-quest to fetch-quest. The character of War and is summed up as "Angry Guy with a Big Sword and Horse", and while the game adknowledges this fact, there is a distinct lack of humanity in the characters, even for demons and angels. The game hopes to be a stepping stone for a larger scale game, and it does build to that.Atmosphere: 4/10The zones are intersting and have a very alien feel to them, however you quickly forget that you are on Earth after leaving the first few zones. There is a lot they could have done with the setting to show a post apocolyptic world without getting stale, however the fantasy aspect seems to take over a bit too much. The areas are pretty, and seem vast, however are often rather small and get old fast.Gameplay: 5/10Basic puzzle-dungeon gameplay with hack and slash combat. It doesn't seek to expand into any new territory, but accomplished what it wants to. The hack and slash style combat is straightforward, giving you combos and allowing you to level new ones. The finishers get annoying after seeing them more than once, and some abilites are insanely powerful.Sound: 6/10War's voice acting could be described as " Christian Bale Batman with some cough drops". While not the worst, all the voice acting in the game is....alright. Up to industry standards, but definately not pushing any boundaries. The music, however, is great though and fits well with the fantasy/war style the game wants to express. Pros:Gameplay is something that ....worksStory is a new take on something we've seenSoundtrack is greatCons:Lacks the Human aesthetic the first level hasPoor CharacterizationBuy If: You like puzzle-dungeonsYou are intersted in the Four Horsemen storyYou want to play Darksiders 2

												I am not sure I can recommend this game but to be fair it was fun at times. Thing is, it gets repetitive and boring and a chore to finish which made me regret every playing it. The metacritic score is exaggerated in my opinion. The game's mechanics are good and you get some cool moves. If you are a fan of Devil May Cry games, then I think you'll like this one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												As an achievement hunter I'm really really sad that the majority of my achievements never registered. It's a known issue, but that really doesn't excuse it.. Anyway, Darksiders has a few flaws but honestly it's actually more than solid enough to recommend it. The story's quite good, the characters are interesting and the gameplay is satisfying - both the puzzling and the battle system. That said, Darksiders doesn't do achievers justice. A person like me wants to experience all the game's got to offer and get recognised for it. But if you just follow the story you will run into everything by default. Sure, there are a few things that require going out of your way to obtain, like the Abyssal Armor or the Legendary add-ons, but by then you've accomplished everything and the only thing that remains is the final boss and the credit screen. Because of that, getting that fat loot doesn't feel nearly as rewarding as it should have. The game looks like it could offer so much more to people who drive themselves to explore every part of its world, but it just doesn't. I wonder if Darksiders 2 will make up for that? I'm itching to find out.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												This game is a great third-person, button masher/beat-em-up, that includes many different, cleaver and satisfying puzzles to advance to different stages. These puzzles include the use of jumping/gliding, explosives, grappling hooks, slowing time and portals. The first part of the game you will be also doing a few cool arenas with different objectives such as aerial kills and protecting zombies.Bosses are really fun and have really cool mechanics, if you liked raiding it WoW I would defiantly recommend thisThere are only a few bad things I can say about this game. I found some with lots of crashing and buggy achievements/hand ins. You may also require a controller as it is a port.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												This is one of the coolest games I've ever played. Many people would call this a Zelda clone. Sure, you've got Zelda-inspired dungeons and exploration, but you also have a combat system similar to God of War and other action games. You can also level up weapons to unlock new skills and combos. I know what you're thinking. All of this has been done before, right? But not all of it has been put together into one amazing game. The designers managed to pull tons of styles together into one game and execute it flawlessly. Not to mention, the story is badass. Oh, and War's version of Navi? A floating spirit voiced by Mark Hamill. In his Joker voice. Seriously, this game kicks♥♥♥♥♥ Go play it now.
